Gilbert NyandejeGilbert Nyandeje,"ACDF 2023 Barometer Report is out and these are some of the key take aways from the Kigali Deliberations:ÃÂ Â Â The intersection of cybersecurity, digital trust, and Africa's digital economy is pivotal for a prosperous and secure future. Unity and a shared vision are imperative to build a resilient digital Africa, fostering innovation and prosperity for all Africans.ÃÂ Â Â With the proliferation of advanced technologies like Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning, there is an urgent need for robust cybersecurity measures. Shockingly, around 90% of African businesses lack such measures, contributing to a 76% increase in cybercrime in certain nations.ÃÂ Â Â Global cybersecurity lacks diversity with only 24% women, 9% in Africa. There is need for more efforts that should beÂ focused to bridge the gender gap.ÃÂ Â Â African banks face growing challenges in data privacy and protection, with over 80% of countries already practicing or having data protection laws. To address this, banks must consider data storage, custody, and security, as well as internal practices, contracts with third parties, and monetary insurance.ÃÂ Â Â Cyber diplomacy is a vital aspect of international cooperation, particularly in Africa, where states collaborate to address issues that technology cannot solve. Countries like Germany and the U.S. have appointed cyber ambassadors, demonstrating the growing interest in this realm of diplomacy. African countries are developing digital teams within their Ministry of Foreign Affairs and across government. As cyber threats become more pervasive, it is essential to leverage its potential for collaboration and diplomacy.For more information:",Co-Founder & CEO at Threatsealâ„¢l ENOVISE & AFRICA CYBER DEFENSE FORUMCo-Founder & CEO at Threatsealâ„¢l ENOVISE & AFRICA CYBER DEFENSE FORUM,,,,"['AfricaCyberDefenseForum', 'ACDF', 'ShapingTheFutureOfCyberDefense', 'BarometerReport2023']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Malek BEN AYEDMalek BEN AYED,"Cyber Vulnerabilities and Growing Concerns: Insights from the World Economic Forum 2024 ReportSimultaneously, the rapid integration of advanced technologies is exposing a broader subset of the global population to potential digital and physical exploitation. Organized crime networks will increasingly adopt blended business models, utilizing new technologies to diversify illicit funding and fragment the physical presence of organized crime. Cybercrime will continue to spread to parts of Asia West, and Southern Africa as affluence grows, and internet connectivity brings large swathes of the global population online.There is a growing concern around the risk of cybercrime and cybersecurity among business leaders in developing regions. It ranks among the top 10 risks over the next two years for markets already grappling with higher levels of criminality, such as Cameroon, Mali, Thailand, and the United Arab Emirates.For all businesses seeking KPIs about global events, check out the full report.hashtag#cybersecurityhashtag#weforumhashtag#AFRICAhashtag#MENA",Business Development | CyberSecurity | Africa FrancophoneBusiness Development | CyberSecurity | Africa Francophone,,,,"['cybersecurity', 'weforum', 'AFRICA', 'MENA']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

KYC AML GuideKYC AML Guide,"Intelligence sharing, cross-checking global databases, andhashtag#biometricverificationto thwart terrorism risk at global sporting eventğŸŒ INTERPOL recently deployed a specialized intelligence support team to aid CÃ´te d'Ivoire in securing the Africa Cup of Nations 2024 in the face of high-risk terrorism threats.ğŸ† With 24 national soccer teams competing across multiple cities from January 13 to February 11, ensuring the safety of the three million fans traveling to CÃ´te d'Ivoire became paramount.ğŸ›¡ï¸ Local police collaborated with INTERPOL to equip frontline officers with essential global tools for identifying potential threats at border checkpoints.âœˆï¸ An expert INTERPOL team worked alongside CÃ´te d'Ivoire's national police, cross-referencing passenger manifests against criminal databases to apprehend suspected criminals upon arrival.ğŸš” In light of the Sahel region's proximity, where extremist terrorist groups often operate, the police were trained to perform biometric checks against records of suspected terrorists, minimizing spill-over risks during the CAN.ğŸ’¼ General Youssouf Kouyate, Director of CÃ´te d'Ivoire's National Police, praised INTERPOL's comprehensive support, ensuring that the event's joy was not overshadowed by security threats.ğŸ¤Cyril GOUT, INTERPOL's Acting Executive Director of Police Services, emphasized the importance of international cooperation in ensuring safety, highlighting the collaboration among 196 countries in the global law enforcement family.ğŸŒ The Abidjan INTERPOL National Central Bureau played a crucial role, connecting sea, air, and land borders to INTERPOL systems and training officers nationwide in database usage.ğŸ’» Ahead of the event, specialized training sessions and cybersecurity support were provided to enhance regional security and intelligence sharing.Law enforcement's cooperation underscores importance of data cross checks from global databases and use of biometric tech to identify potential suspect who could pose a risk to disruption of such events.AsCristian Barbieripolicy analyst atINTERPOLWAPIS program remarked in his post, ""WAPIS officers, with the invaluable support of the Head of DACOREs network, provided real-time access to critical information, facilitating prompt threat identification and fostering collaboration among law enforcement agencies. This enabled comprehensive data cross-checks against national, regional, and global databases.""Source: Interpol websitehashtag#INTERPOLhashtag#AfricaCupofNationshashtag#Securityhashtag#LawEnforcementhashtag#globalcollaborationhashtag#databasechecks",9Â 251Â abonnÃ©s9Â 251Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['biometricverification', 'INTERPOL', 'AfricaCupofNations', 'Security', 'LawEnforcement', 'globalcollaboration', 'databasechecks']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Kim HawkeyKim Hawkey,"CÃ´te d'Ivoire Legal Alert:The Council of Ministers has adopted a Bill that provides for the establishment of a register of beneficial owners of legal entities and legal arrangements. It will set up a system for the identification of business partners and people who exercise effective control over legal entities.The Bill provides for a central register of beneficial owners at the registry of the Abidjan Commercial Court, which will bring together all the national data contained in various registers which are kept in each court, with a view to ensuring availability of this information and to guarantee the transparency and security of the business environment.The Council of Ministers has also adopted a decree relating to the implementation of targeted financial sanctions for financing terrorism and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.Afriwisehashtag#beneficialownershiphashtag#amlhashtag#legalalerthashtag#terrorismfinancinghashtag#cotedivoirehashtag#effectivecontrolhashtag#financialsanctionshashtag#wmdhashtag#beneficialownerhashtag#transparency",Chief Content & Product Officer at Afriwise | Independent ContractorChief Content & Product Officer at Afriwise | Independent Contractor,,,,"['beneficialownership', 'aml', 'legalalert', 'terrorismfinancing', 'cotedivoire', 'effectivecontrol', 'financialsanctions', 'wmd', 'beneficialowner', 'transparency']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

The arrest of a suspected senior member of the OPERA1ER cybercrime gang in CÃ´te d'Ivoire highlights the ongoing efforts to combat cybercriminals operating in Africa, Asia, and Latin America.2. OPERA1ER, also known as Bluebottle and other aliases, was responsible for stealing millions of dollars in over 30 attacks on financial institutions and mobile banking services since 2018.3. KYC AML GuideKYC AML Guide,"Intelligence sharing, cross-checking global databases, and#biometricverificationto thwart terrorism risk at global sporting eventğŸŒ INTERPOL recently deployed a specialized intelligence support team to aid CÃ´te d'Ivoire in securing the Africa Cup of Nations 2024 in the face of high-risk terrorism threats.ğŸ† With 24 national soccer teams competing across multiple cities from January 13 to February 11, ensuring the safety of the three million fans traveling to CÃ´te d'Ivoire became paramount.ğŸ›¡ï¸ Local police collaborated with INTERPOL to equip frontline officers with essential global tools for identifying potential threats at border checkpoints.âœˆï¸ An expert INTERPOL team worked alongside CÃ´te d'Ivoire's national police, cross-referencing passenger manifests against criminal databases to apprehend suspected criminals upon arrival.ğŸš” In light of the Sahel region's proximity, where extremist terrorist groups often operate, the police were trained to perform biometric checks against records of suspected terrorists, minimizing spill-over risks during the CAN.ğŸ’¼ General Youssouf Kouyate, Director of CÃ´te d'Ivoire's National Police, praised INTERPOL's comprehensive support, ensuring that the event's joy was not overshadowed by security threats.ğŸ¤Cyril GOUT, INTERPOL's Acting Executive Director of Police Services, emphasized the importance of international cooperation in ensuring safety, highlighting the collaboration among 196 countries in the global law enforcement family.ğŸŒ The Abidjan INTERPOL National Central Bureau played a crucial role, connecting sea, air, and land borders to INTERPOL systems and training officers nationwide in database usage.ğŸ’» Ahead of the event, specialized training sessions and cybersecurity support were provided to enhance regional security and intelligence sharing.Law enforcement's cooperation underscores importance of data cross checks from global databases and use of biometric tech to identify potential suspect who could pose a risk to disruption of such events.AsCristian Barbieripolicy analyst atINTERPOLWAPIS program remarked in his post, ""WAPIS officers, with the invaluable support of the Head of DACOREs network, provided real-time access to critical information, facilitating prompt threat identification and fostering collaboration among law enforcement agencies. This enabled comprehensive data cross-checks against national, regional, and global databases.""Source: Interpol website#INTERPOL#AfricaCupofNations#Security#LawEnforcement#globalcollaboration#databasechecks",9Â 251Â abonnÃ©s9Â 251Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['biometricverification', 'INTERPOL', 'AfricaCupofNations', 'Security', 'LawEnforcement', 'globalcollaboration', 'databasechecks']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

author: Michael Lopez ğŸ›¡ï¸Michael Lopez ğŸ›¡ï¸,"ğŸš¨ Cybersecurity Alert: Crucial Updates You Need to Know ğŸš¨1ï¸âƒ£ OPERA1ER Cybercrime Group's Leader Arrested: The suspected leader of the cybercrime group OPERA1ER, accused of stealing $30 million through various cybercrime activities, has been apprehended in CÃ´te d'Ivoire by Interpol. This successful operation underscores the crucial role of threat data exchange and collaboration between public and private sector partners.2ï¸âƒ£ Ransomware Hits Japan's Port of Nagoya: In a disruptive incident, the Port of Nagoya in Japan was forced to halt operations due to a ransomware attack attributed to the LockBit 3.0 ransomware group. With the port being a key shipping hub for Toyota, the attack's impact is being closely monitored.3ï¸âƒ£ Mustang Panda Targets European Governments: The Chinese threat group SmugX has been employing an attack vector called HTML Smuggling to plant the PlugX remote access Trojan (RAT) within governmental ministries across Europe. This highlights the necessity for advanced detection measures and increased cybersecurity measures within public entities.4ï¸âƒ£ Microsoft's Potential Ransomware Solution: Microsoft could potentially address ransomware attacks by rate-limiting the ""CreateFile"" API used to access files on Windows. However, implementing this solution would require addressing practical complexities and potential effects on compatibility.5ï¸âƒ£ Critical Fortinet VPN Bug Exploited: Researchers have developed an exploit code for a critical remote code execution vulnerability in Fortinet's FortiGate SSL VPNs. With approximately 340,000 unpatched FortiGate devices vulnerable to the flaw, it's a stern reminder of the need for regular patch updates.6ï¸âƒ£ SSH Servers Hit in 'Proxyjacking' Attacks: Akamai SIRT researchers have discovered a new attack type - proxyjacking, which involves exploiting vulnerable SSH servers to launch Docker services. This clandestine use of network bandwidth for monetary gains further emphasizes the need for constant vigilance and proactive security measures.Spread the word to help raise cybersecurity awareness, and follow if you like this kind of content. Stay informed, stay secure.#CyberSecurityAwareness#InfoSec#CyberSecurity#OPERA1ER#LockBitRansomware#MustangPanda#MicrosoftRansomwareSolution#FortinetVPN#Proxyjacking","CISSP, CASP+, GIAC, Sec+CISSP, CASP+, GIAC, Sec+",,,,"['CyberSecurityAwareness', 'InfoSec', 'CyberSecurity', 'OPERA1ER', 'LockBitRansomware', 'MustangPanda', 'MicrosoftRansomwareSolution', 'FortinetVPN', 'Proxyjacking']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

KYC AML GuideKYC AML Guide,"Intelligence sharing, cross-checking global databases, and#biometricverificationto thwart terrorism risk at global sporting eventğŸŒ INTERPOL recently deployed a specialized intelligence support team to aid CÃ´te d'Ivoire in securing the Africa Cup of Nations 2024 in the face of high-risk terrorism threats.ğŸ† With 24 national soccer teams competing across multiple cities from January 13 to February 11, ensuring the safety of the three million fans traveling to CÃ´te d'Ivoire became paramount.ğŸ›¡ï¸ Local police collaborated with INTERPOL to equip frontline officers with essential global tools for identifying potential threats at border checkpoints.âœˆï¸ An expert INTERPOL team worked alongside CÃ´te d'Ivoire's national police, cross-referencing passenger manifests against criminal databases to apprehend suspected criminals upon arrival.ğŸš” In light of the Sahel region's proximity, where extremist terrorist groups often operate, the police were trained to perform biometric checks against records of suspected terrorists, minimizing spill-over risks during the CAN.ğŸ’¼ General Youssouf Kouyate, Director of CÃ´te d'Ivoire's National Police, praised INTERPOL's comprehensive support, ensuring that the event's joy was not overshadowed by security threats.ğŸ¤Cyril GOUT, INTERPOL's Acting Executive Director of Police Services, emphasized the importance of international cooperation in ensuring safety, highlighting the collaboration among 196 countries in the global law enforcement family.ğŸŒ The Abidjan INTERPOL National Central Bureau played a crucial role, connecting sea, air, and land borders to INTERPOL systems and training officers nationwide in database usage.ğŸ’» Ahead of the event, specialized training sessions and cybersecurity support were provided to enhance regional security and intelligence sharing.Law enforcement's cooperation underscores importance of data cross checks from global databases and use of biometric tech to identify potential suspect who could pose a risk to disruption of such events.AsCristian Barbieripolicy analyst atINTERPOLWAPIS program remarked in his post, ""WAPIS officers, with the invaluable support of the Head of DACOREs network, provided real-time access to critical information, facilitating prompt threat identification and fostering collaboration among law enforcement agencies. This enabled comprehensive data cross-checks against national, regional, and global databases.""Source: Interpol website#INTERPOL#AfricaCupofNations#Security#LawEnforcement#globalcollaboration#databasechecks",9Â 251Â abonnÃ©s9Â 251Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['biometricverification', 'INTERPOL', 'AfricaCupofNations', 'Security', 'LawEnforcement', 'globalcollaboration', 'databasechecks']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Kim HawkeyKim Hawkey,"CÃ´te d'Ivoire Legal Alert:The Council of Ministers has adopted a Bill that provides for the establishment of a register of beneficial owners of legal entities and legal arrangements. It will set up a system for the identification of business partners and people who exercise effective control over legal entities.The Bill provides for a central register of beneficial owners at the registry of the Abidjan Commercial Court, which will bring together all the national data contained in various registers which are kept in each court, with a view to ensuring availability of this information and to guarantee the transparency and security of the business environment.The Council of Ministers has also adopted a decree relating to the implementation of targeted financial sanctions for financing terrorism and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.Afriwise#beneficialownership#aml#legalalert#terrorismfinancing#cotedivoire#effectivecontrol#financialsanctions#wmd#beneficialowner#transparency",Chief Content & Product Officer at Afriwise | Independent ContractorChief Content & Product Officer at Afriwise | Independent Contractor,,,,"['beneficialownership', 'aml', 'legalalert', 'terrorismfinancing', 'cotedivoire', 'effectivecontrol', 'financialsanctions', 'wmd', 'beneficialowner', 'transparency']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

author: The Record from Recorded Future NewsThe Record from Recorded Future News,"Top suspect in OPERA1ER cybercrime operation arrested in Africa. Here's what you need to know:1. The arrest of a suspected senior member of the OPERA1ER cybercrime gang in CÃ´te d'Ivoire highlights the ongoing efforts to combat cybercriminals operating in Africa, Asia, and Latin America.2. OPERA1ER, also known as Bluebottle and other aliases, was responsible for stealing millions of dollars in over 30 attacks on financial institutions and mobile banking services since 2018.3. This successful operation, named Operation Nervone, involved collaboration between international law enforcement agencies, cybersecurity companies, and government entities, emphasizing the importance of public-private partnerships in tackling sophisticated cyber threat actors.Learn more by visiting The Record from Recorded Future News:https://lnkd.in/e5FwWHEZ",12Â 655Â abonnÃ©s12Â 655Â abonnÃ©s,,,,[];;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Plateforme YARISPlateforme YARIS,"Pour la version Fr voir les commentairesThe increase in cyber security incidents affecting ships and port infrastructures is a significant concern for the maritime industry. The survey conducted by the International Association of Classification Societies (IACS) revealing that nearly 70% of maritime companies have experienced a cyber attack highlights the severity of the issue.Here are some key implications and considerations:1. Vulnerabilities in Operational Technology (OT): Ships and port infrastructures heavily rely on operational technology systems for various critical functions. These systems include navigation, cargo management, communication, and safety systems. Cyber attacks targeting these systems can disrupt operations, compromise safety, and lead to financial losses. Maritime companies must assess and address vulnerabilities in their OT infrastructure to mitigate the risk of cyber attacks.2. Data Breaches and Information Security: Maritime companies handle sensitive information such as cargo manifests, vessel routes, crew details, and customer data. A cyber attack can result in data breaches, leading to the exposure or theft of sensitive information. This can have legal, financial, and reputational consequences for the affected companies. Robust information security measures, including encryption, access controls, and regular data backups, are essential to protect against data breaches.3. Supply Chain Risks: The interconnected nature of the maritime industry poses supply chain risks in terms of cyber security.4. Regulatory Compliance: The maritime industry is subject to various regulatory frameworks and standards related to cyber security. Compliance with the International Maritime Organization (IMO) guideline on maritime cyber risk management is vital to ensure the security and resilience of ships and port infrastructures. 5. Cybersecurity Awareness and Training: Building a strong cyber security culture. Creating awareness about the potential consequences of cyber attacks can help foster a proactive approach towards cyber security.By adopting a comprehensive approach that includes technological safeguards, employee training, and collaboration with industry partners, maritime companies can enhance their resilience against cyber threats and protect critical operations and infrastructure.https://yaris.site/en/YARIS##yaoundearchitecture#maritimedomain#informationsystem#gulfofguinea#gogin#africa#MDA#europeanunion#EU#informationsystem#cybersecurity#dataprivacy#datamanagement#complianve#domainemaritimeCRESMAOCRESMAO EIMSCRESMACINTER-REGIONALDr. Ifesinachi O.Expertise France CÃ´te d'Ivoire (golfe de GuinÃ©e)Expertise FranceMaritime Analysis and Operations Centre (Narcotics) - MAOC (N)CECLANT Golfe de GuinÃ©eInstitute for Security StudiesGulf of Guinea Maritime Institute",1Â 402Â abonnÃ©s1Â 402Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['yaoundearchitecture', 'maritimedomain', 'informationsystem', 'gulfofguinea', 'gogin', 'africa', 'MDA', 'europeanunion', 'EU', 'informationsystem', 'cybersecurity', 'dataprivacy', 'datamanagement', 'complianve', 'domainemaritime']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Mohamed KAROUIAMohamed KAROUIA,"We are honoured to be one of the 50 panelists at the first edition of the â€˜â€˜Africa Postal Leaders Forumâ€™â€™, to be held from 3 to 5 July in Abidjan, CÃ´te d'Ivoire.This first UPU Africa Postal Leaders Forum will bring together postal leaders#leadersfrom nearly 40 African countries as well as politicians, policymakers, regulators, and partners to discuss how to accelerate the#modernizationof Posts in Africa.Development partners, including the West African Development Bank#bank#development, the African Development Bank Group, the World Health Organization (WHO) and members of the UPU Consultative committee will be present.Congratulations toIsaac GNAMBA-YAO, Chairman of the Board of Directors, Universal Postal Union, for making this project a reality.#africaAfrica Posts play a central role in socio-economic development and in giving citizens and businesses greater access to#eCommerce. They are therefore well placed to provide innovative#digitalservices, bridge connectivity gaps and thus contribute to social, digital and financial#inclusion.On Day 2 from 14:30-16:30 local time, the Forum will focus on the topic#Cybersecurity: Securing#postalinfrastructure- how to get it right?In recent years, the world has witnessed a significant increase in#cyberthreatstargeting commercial organizations and national infrastructures. With the increased#digitalizationof the#economyand#postalservices, comes an increased risk. These attacks pose serious risks to the integrity, confidentiality, and availability of essential postal services. How do we build harmonized / collaborative protection between sectors, how do we foster#secureand#sustainable#digitizationof posts?The session aims to:- Raise awareness about the escalating cybersecurity threats.- Foster collaboration and information sharing between stakeholders to enhance the overall cybersecurity situation.- Identify best practices, technologies, and policies to strengthen the resilience of postal systems against cyber threats.Moderator:Â Gertrude KONE KOUASSIÃ©, Chairperson of the Digital Economy and Enterprise Commission of the CÃ´te d'Ivoire General Trade ConfederationSpeakers:Â Mohamed KAROUIA, CEO, Executive Digital Partners, Serge Zongo, Cybersecurity focal point,Â International Telecommunication UnionÂ - Tracy Hackshaw, .POST Business Unit Manager,#UPU,Â LaÃ¯cana COULIBALY, Cybersecurity Expert, IFG Afrique,Â Rajkumar Velagapudi, Founder & CEO,Â TAO Digital Solutions",Founder and Managing PartnerFounder and Managing Partner,,,,"['leaders', 'modernization', 'bank', 'development', 'africa', 'eCommerce', 'digital', 'inclusion', 'Cybersecurity', 'postalinfrastructure', 'cyberthreats', 'digitalization', 'economy', 'postalservices', 'secure', 'sustainable', 'digitization', 'UPU']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Oyeniyi FaleyeOyeniyi Faleye,"Promise kept.To be honest, I was a bit nervous when I announced yesterday I would hit the ground running with a new newsletter and even had the courage to name it Distill Africa. And then wrote the letter would no longer be called The Game Plan.Why feel uncomfortable? I had made similar announcements in the past but for some reason, I never got to execute. My bad. But I had to face my fears. So, I woke up this morning at about 2:24 am and quickly ironed my clothes because I have a meeting later today. Then, I got to work. Thank God, I did it. So,Â  you are enlisted as my accountability partners.Anyways, regarding this issue, I just took some pages off The Big Deal, ""The CB Insight of Africa"", thatâ€™s my moniker for the company. The Big Deal combs the startup ecosystem in Africa to ferret the minutest deals on the continent. The Big Deal noted that Launch Africa is the most prolific investor in Africa. Well, other tidbits include the GSMA report 2023, Kasperskyâ€™s cybersecurity report and then Chude Jideonwoâ€™s invitation to speak at the Oxford Africa Conference.See you on Friday.#distiilafrica#africa#newafrica#startup#startupafrica#cybersecurity#mobilemoneyinafrica#thebigdeal#launchafrica#chudejideonwo#oxfordafricaconference#oxforduniversity",Strategy & Marketing Thought LeaderStrategy & Marketing Thought Leader,,,,"['distiilafrica', 'africa', 'newafrica', 'startup', 'startupafrica', 'cybersecurity', 'mobilemoneyinafrica', 'thebigdeal', 'launchafrica', 'chudejideonwo', 'oxfordafricaconference', 'oxforduniversity']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Angela KilimoAngela Kilimo,"CIArb @ 40: International ADR ConferenceDAY 2: A climactic day that began with a CIArb Chairmans Roundtable discussion on the Cohesive Growth of CIArb across Africa, addressing the question of Diversity and Inclusion. Currently, Africa has 3 women as CIArb chairman. It was exciting to learn thatChartered Institute of Arbitrators Kenya Branchhas been involved in the founding of the branches represented on the panel: Nigeria, Zambia and Rwanda with Nigeria now walking with the branches of Sierra Leone, Cameroon, CÃ´te d'Ivoire and Rwanda. These efforts will open up the continent and enable African voices to be heard in the Arbitration space.There were interesting discussions on Quantifying Damages in Arbitration.Mrinal Jainexpounded on assessment of damages to be awarded.Ndanga Kamauemphasised the importance of an Arbitrator understanding the role of damages by assessing the standard and mitigating factors that could reduce the damages. Stephen Finzio addressed the use of bifurcation in assessing damages resulting in the benefit of eliminating costs while also risking elongating the arbitration process.Paul Ngotho HSC, C. Arb, L.L.Mhighlighted challenges in proving damages such as lack of clarity in the prayers and unjustified prayers for interest.The panel on Data Protection & Cyber Security in the Face of Technological Advancement in Arbitration was introduced by a keynote speech by the Data Protection CommissionerImmaculate Kassait, MBSwho highlighted the changes that the Data Protection Act introduced and the challenges that even the ODPC faces with cyber attack risks. There is a need for effective implementation of the legal framework and Arbitrators through their work, contribute to the development of best practices in the Data Protection space.In the afternoon, I attended the Mediation caucus with two panels. The first panel addressed the Regional Analysis of Mediation as a Tool to Drive Competitive Global Business and Access to Justice. The illustrious panelists JusticeFred Ochieng,Lady Justice Joyce Aluochand ProfessorMaria Nzomooutlined the progress of Mediation in Kenya as advanced by the Judiciary and the critical role women have played in international peace efforts such as the landmark Resolution on Women, Peace and Security. The second panel did a practical assessment of mediation advocacy skills.Faith Monydefined the role of advocates in mediation while DrOkubo Yufnalisspelled out the skills a mediator requires for success. They also addressed the shift in the legal profession thanks to mediation and the distinction between Arbitration and Mediation.The Conference closed with a Mega Book Launch of 12 books on ADR by Africans for Africans that was graced by the CIArb Kenya Patron, her LadyshipCJ Martha Koomeand a splendid Gala Dinner and Awards Ceremony. This was an encouragement to pursue my passion fearlessly.",Law Student | ACIArb | Certified MediatorLaw Student | ACIArb | Certified Mediator,,,,[];;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Cyber Africa Forum (CAF)Cyber Africa Forum (CAF),"[#Englishbelow] L'IA et la cybersÃ©curitÃ© seront au cÅ“ur du#CAF2024!La quatriÃ¨me Ã©dition du#CAF, qui se tiendra les 15 et 16 avril prochains Ã  Abidjan, en CÃ´te d'Ivoire, abordera les enjeux de l'intelligence artificielle (IA) et de la cybersÃ©curitÃ© en Afrique.L'IA est une technologie prometteuse qui a le potentiel de rÃ©volutionner de nombreux secteurs, notamment la santÃ©, l'Ã©ducation et l'industrie mais qui soulÃ¨ve Ã©galement de nombreux enjeux. Face Ã  l'Ã©volution rapide et complexe des cyberattaques, qui reprÃ©sentent un coÃ»t Ã©levÃ©, il est impÃ©ratif pour les entreprises et les gouvernements africains de se munir des outils nÃ©cessaires pour contrer ces menaces.Le CAF2024 sera donc une plateforme privilÃ©giÃ©e pour les acteurs clÃ©s des secteurs public et privÃ©, notamment des experts en IA, afin de dÃ©battre des stratÃ©gies de renforcement de la sÃ©curitÃ© informatique en Afrique.Les discussions du forum porteront sur des sujets essentiels, tels que :- Les derniÃ¨res innovations et tendances en IA et cybersÃ©curitÃ©.- Les stratÃ©gies Ã©prouvÃ©es pour sÃ©curiser les infrastructures informatiques africaines.- L'Ã©laboration de partenariats public-privÃ© robustes, axÃ©s sur l'amÃ©lioration de la cybersÃ©curitÃ© sur le continent.--AI and cybersecurity will be at the heart of#CAF2024!The fourth edition of#CAF, to be held on April 15 and 16 in Abidjan, CÃ´te d'Ivoire, will address the challenges of artificial intelligence (AI) and cybersecurity in Africa.AI is a promising technology with the potential to revolutionize many sectors, including healthcare, education and industry, but it also raises many challenges. In the face of rapidly evolving and complex cyber-attacks, which represent a high cost, it is imperative for African businesses and governments to equip themselves with the necessary tools to counter these threats.#CAF2024will therefore be a privileged platform for key players from the public and private sectors, including AI experts, to discuss strategies for strengthening IT security in Africa.Discussions at the forum will cover key topics such as:- The latest innovations and trends in AI and cybersecurity.- Proven strategies for securing African IT infrastructures.- The development of robust public-private partnerships focused on improving cybersecurity on the continent.#CyberAfricaForum#CAF#Cybersecurity#IAhttps://lnkd.in/ekbYmG9n",13Â 908Â abonnÃ©s13Â 908Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['Englishbelow', 'CAF2024', 'CAF', 'CAF2024', 'CAF', 'CAF2024', 'CyberAfricaForum', 'CAF', 'Cybersecurity', 'IA']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

author: The Record from Recorded Future NewsThe Record from Recorded Future News,"Top suspect in OPERA1ER cybercrime operation arrested in Africa. Here's what you need to know:1. The arrest of a suspected senior member of the OPERA1ER cybercrime gang in CÃ´te d'Ivoire highlights the ongoing efforts to combat cybercriminals operating in Africa, Asia, and Latin America.2. OPERA1ER, also known as Bluebottle and other aliases, was responsible for stealing millions of dollars in over 30 attacks on financial institutions and mobile banking services since 2018.3. This successful operation, named Operation Nervone, involved collaboration between international law enforcement agencies, cybersecurity companies, and government entities, emphasizing the importance of public-private partnerships in tackling sophisticated cyber threat actors.Learn more by visiting The Record from Recorded Future News:https://lnkd.in/e5FwWHEZ",12Â 655Â abonnÃ©s12Â 655Â abonnÃ©s,,,,[];;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Plateforme YARISPlateforme YARIS,"Pour la version Fr voir les commentairesThe increase in cyber security incidents affecting ships and port infrastructures is a significant concern for the maritime industry. The survey conducted by the International Association of Classification Societies (IACS) revealing that nearly 70% of maritime companies have experienced a cyber attack highlights the severity of the issue.Here are some key implications and considerations:1. Vulnerabilities in Operational Technology (OT): Ships and port infrastructures heavily rely on operational technology systems for various critical functions. These systems include navigation, cargo management, communication, and safety systems. Cyber attacks targeting these systems can disrupt operations, compromise safety, and lead to financial losses. Maritime companies must assess and address vulnerabilities in their OT infrastructure to mitigate the risk of cyber attacks.2. Data Breaches and Information Security: Maritime companies handle sensitive information such as cargo manifests, vessel routes, crew details, and customer data. A cyber attack can result in data breaches, leading to the exposure or theft of sensitive information. This can have legal, financial, and reputational consequences for the affected companies. Robust information security measures, including encryption, access controls, and regular data backups, are essential to protect against data breaches.3. Supply Chain Risks: The interconnected nature of the maritime industry poses supply chain risks in terms of cyber security.4. Regulatory Compliance: The maritime industry is subject to various regulatory frameworks and standards related to cyber security. Compliance with the International Maritime Organization (IMO) guideline on maritime cyber risk management is vital to ensure the security and resilience of ships and port infrastructures. 5. Cybersecurity Awareness and Training: Building a strong cyber security culture. Creating awareness about the potential consequences of cyber attacks can help foster a proactive approach towards cyber security.By adopting a comprehensive approach that includes technological safeguards, employee training, and collaboration with industry partners, maritime companies can enhance their resilience against cyber threats and protect critical operations and infrastructure.https://yaris.site/en/YARIS##yaoundearchitecture#maritimedomain#informationsystem#gulfofguinea#gogin#africa#MDA#europeanunion#EU#informationsystem#cybersecurity#dataprivacy#datamanagement#complianve#domainemaritimeCRESMAOCRESMAO EIMSCRESMACINTER-REGIONALDr. Ifesinachi O.Expertise France CÃ´te d'Ivoire (golfe de GuinÃ©e)Expertise FranceMaritime Analysis and Operations Centre (Narcotics) - MAOC (N)CECLANT Golfe de GuinÃ©eInstitute for Security StudiesGulf of Guinea Maritime Institute",1Â 402Â abonnÃ©s1Â 402Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['yaoundearchitecture', 'maritimedomain', 'informationsystem', 'gulfofguinea', 'gogin', 'africa', 'MDA', 'europeanunion', 'EU', 'informationsystem', 'cybersecurity', 'dataprivacy', 'datamanagement', 'complianve', 'domainemaritime']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Mohamed KAROUIAMohamed KAROUIA,"We are honoured to be one of the 50 panelists at the first edition of the â€˜â€˜Africa Postal Leaders Forumâ€™â€™, to be held from 3 to 5 July in Abidjan, CÃ´te d'Ivoire.This first UPU Africa Postal Leaders Forum will bring together postal leaders#leadersfrom nearly 40 African countries as well as politicians, policymakers, regulators, and partners to discuss how to accelerate the#modernizationof Posts in Africa.Development partners, including the West African Development Bank#bank#development, the African Development Bank Group, the World Health Organization (WHO) and members of the UPU Consultative committee will be present.Congratulations toIsaac GNAMBA-YAO, Chairman of the Board of Directors, Universal Postal Union, for making this project a reality.#africaAfrica Posts play a central role in socio-economic development and in giving citizens and businesses greater access to#eCommerce. They are therefore well placed to provide innovative#digitalservices, bridge connectivity gaps and thus contribute to social, digital and financial#inclusion.On Day 2 from 14:30-16:30 local time, the Forum will focus on the topic#Cybersecurity: Securing#postalinfrastructure- how to get it right?In recent years, the world has witnessed a significant increase in#cyberthreatstargeting commercial organizations and national infrastructures. With the increased#digitalizationof the#economyand#postalservices, comes an increased risk. These attacks pose serious risks to the integrity, confidentiality, and availability of essential postal services. How do we build harmonized / collaborative protection between sectors, how do we foster#secureand#sustainable#digitizationof posts?The session aims to:- Raise awareness about the escalating cybersecurity threats.- Foster collaboration and information sharing between stakeholders to enhance the overall cybersecurity situation.- Identify best practices, technologies, and policies to strengthen the resilience of postal systems against cyber threats.Moderator:Â Gertrude KONE KOUASSIÃ©, Chairperson of the Digital Economy and Enterprise Commission of the CÃ´te d'Ivoire General Trade ConfederationSpeakers:Â Mohamed KAROUIA, CEO, Executive Digital Partners, Serge Zongo, Cybersecurity focal point,Â International Telecommunication UnionÂ - Tracy Hackshaw, .POST Business Unit Manager,#UPU,Â LaÃ¯cana COULIBALY, Cybersecurity Expert, IFG Afrique,Â Rajkumar Velagapudi, Founder & CEO,Â TAO Digital Solutions",Founder and Managing PartnerFounder and Managing Partner,,,,"['leaders', 'modernization', 'bank', 'development', 'africa', 'eCommerce', 'digital', 'inclusion', 'Cybersecurity', 'postalinfrastructure', 'cyberthreats', 'digitalization', 'economy', 'postalservices', 'secure', 'sustainable', 'digitization', 'UPU']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Oyeniyi FaleyeOyeniyi Faleye,"Promise kept.To be honest, I was a bit nervous when I announced yesterday I would hit the ground running with a new newsletter and even had the courage to name it Distill Africa. And then wrote the letter would no longer be called The Game Plan.Why feel uncomfortable? I had made similar announcements in the past but for some reason, I never got to execute. My bad. But I had to face my fears. So, I woke up this morning at about 2:24 am and quickly ironed my clothes because I have a meeting later today. Then, I got to work. Thank God, I did it. So,Â  you are enlisted as my accountability partners.Anyways, regarding this issue, I just took some pages off The Big Deal, ""The CB Insight of Africa"", thatâ€™s my moniker for the company. The Big Deal combs the startup ecosystem in Africa to ferret the minutest deals on the continent. The Big Deal noted that Launch Africa is the most prolific investor in Africa. Well, other tidbits include the GSMA report 2023, Kasperskyâ€™s cybersecurity report and then Chude Jideonwoâ€™s invitation to speak at the Oxford Africa Conference.See you on Friday.#distiilafrica#africa#newafrica#startup#startupafrica#cybersecurity#mobilemoneyinafrica#thebigdeal#launchafrica#chudejideonwo#oxfordafricaconference#oxforduniversity",Strategy & Marketing Thought LeaderStrategy & Marketing Thought Leader,,,,"['distiilafrica', 'africa', 'newafrica', 'startup', 'startupafrica', 'cybersecurity', 'mobilemoneyinafrica', 'thebigdeal', 'launchafrica', 'chudejideonwo', 'oxfordafricaconference', 'oxforduniversity']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Angela KilimoAngela Kilimo,"CIArb @ 40: International ADR ConferenceDAY 2: A climactic day that began with a CIArb Chairmans Roundtable discussion on the Cohesive Growth of CIArb across Africa, addressing the question of Diversity and Inclusion. Currently, Africa has 3 women as CIArb chairman. It was exciting to learn thatChartered Institute of Arbitrators Kenya Branchhas been involved in the founding of the branches represented on the panel: Nigeria, Zambia and Rwanda with Nigeria now walking with the branches of Sierra Leone, Cameroon, CÃ´te d'Ivoire and Rwanda. These efforts will open up the continent and enable African voices to be heard in the Arbitration space.There were interesting discussions on Quantifying Damages in Arbitration.Mrinal Jainexpounded on assessment of damages to be awarded.Ndanga Kamauemphasised the importance of an Arbitrator understanding the role of damages by assessing the standard and mitigating factors that could reduce the damages. Stephen Finzio addressed the use of bifurcation in assessing damages resulting in the benefit of eliminating costs while also risking elongating the arbitration process.Paul Ngotho HSC, C. Arb, L.L.Mhighlighted challenges in proving damages such as lack of clarity in the prayers and unjustified prayers for interest.The panel on Data Protection & Cyber Security in the Face of Technological Advancement in Arbitration was introduced by a keynote speech by the Data Protection CommissionerImmaculate Kassait, MBSwho highlighted the changes that the Data Protection Act introduced and the challenges that even the ODPC faces with cyber attack risks. There is a need for effective implementation of the legal framework and Arbitrators through their work, contribute to the development of best practices in the Data Protection space.In the afternoon, I attended the Mediation caucus with two panels. The first panel addressed the Regional Analysis of Mediation as a Tool to Drive Competitive Global Business and Access to Justice. The illustrious panelists JusticeFred Ochieng,Lady Justice Joyce Aluochand ProfessorMaria Nzomooutlined the progress of Mediation in Kenya as advanced by the Judiciary and the critical role women have played in international peace efforts such as the landmark Resolution on Women, Peace and Security. The second panel did a practical assessment of mediation advocacy skills.Faith Monydefined the role of advocates in mediation while DrOkubo Yufnalisspelled out the skills a mediator requires for success. They also addressed the shift in the legal profession thanks to mediation and the distinction between Arbitration and Mediation.The Conference closed with a Mega Book Launch of 12 books on ADR by Africans for Africans that was graced by the CIArb Kenya Patron, her LadyshipCJ Martha Koomeand a splendid Gala Dinner and Awards Ceremony. This was an encouragement to pursue my passion fearlessly.",Law Student | ACIArb | Certified MediatorLaw Student | ACIArb | Certified Mediator,,,,[];;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Daniel AbramsDaniel Abrams,"How Ivorian cyber-scammers help us to understand the magic of theÂ internetAlexander (Sasha) Newell, UniversitÃ© Libre de Bruxelles (ULB) Societies that identify as â€œmodernâ€ tend to categorise people who believe in an invisible world of magic and spirits as irrational and superstitious, thereby excluding them from modernity. But have they ever considered the invisible forces of the digital world might not be that far away fromâ€¦ Continue reading UntitledIn CÃ´te d'Ivoire, brouteurs are known for chasing a life of fame and fortune. Alexander NewellAlexander (Sasha) Newell, UniversitÃ© Libre de Bruxelles (ULB)Societies that identify as â€œmodernâ€ tend to categorise people who believe in an invisible world of magic and spirits as irrational and superstitious, thereby excluding them from modernity. But have they ever considered the invisible forces of the digital world might not be that far away from those of witchcraft?Overlapping worldsAfrican studies have long wrestled with how to represent the phenomena of witchcraft, magic and spirits in cultural life across Africa. Scholars fear that writing about these topics encourages stereotypes about African superstition, yet many recognise the occult is an unavoidable part of the lives of those about whom they are writing.At the same time, in the global North and almost everywhere else in the world, over the last 20 "years our lives have been invaded by invisible agents of which most of us have very little understanding

Itâ€™s easier to address the problem at source than build a whole cleansing capability downstream.This is a great article which explores the importance of regional data governance and is particularly critical as digital trade and smart data becomes more prevalent.",I believe in delivering societally beneficial solutions through the transformative use of AI and data.I believe in delivering societally beneficial solutions through the transformative use of AI and data.,,,,"['datagovernance', 'digitaleconomies', 'FCDO', 'internationaldevelopment']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Gary WarnerGary Warner,"The results from the second round of INTERPOL's fight against the Black Axe and associated West African Confraternities has now been disclosed.  Round One of ""Operation Jackal"" occurred during the final week of September 2022 and resulted in 75 arrests and the seizure of 1.2 Million Euros from bank accounts (along with more than 12,000 SIM Cards!!!)Round Two lasted for two weeks, from 15-29MAY2023, and resulted in 103 arrests and the seizure of more than 2.15 Million Euros from 208 bank accounts! 1,100 suspects were identified.Ireland's fabulous Garda National Economic Crime Bureau was at the top of their game, with 34 arrests made, including 22 arrests for money laundering and ""gangland-style offences.""  Five criminal cases involving Irish businesses resulted in the recovery of 225,655 Euros!Portugal also had great success, with four investigations resulting in the seizure of 1.4 Million Euros!INTERPOL deployed officials to assist in Cote d'Ivoire, Portugal, and Spain, while central offices supported investigators in other participating countries with international criminal database searches and coordination between member countries.  Â Argentina, Australia, Belgium, Brazil, Canada, Cote dâ€™Ivoire, France, Germany, Indonesia, Ireland, Italy, Malaysia, Netherlands, Nigeria, Portugal, South Africa, Spain, Switzerland, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, and the United States all participated in this round, demonstrating just how wide-spread the activities of the Black Axe (aka NeoBlack Movement of Africa) are around the world.INTERPOL describes the organization this way: The Black Axe, and an increasing number of other West African organized crime syndicates, is a violent mafia-style gang renowned for cyber-enabled financial fraud, in particular business email compromise schemes, romance scams, inheritance scams, credit card fraud, tax fraud, advance payment scams and money laundering.",UAB Computer Forensics / DarkTower Threat IntelligenceUAB Computer Forensics / DarkTower Threat Intelligence,,,,[];;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Michael Lopez ğŸ›¡ï¸Michael Lopez ğŸ›¡ï¸,"ğŸš¨ Cybersecurity Alert: Crucial Updates You Need to Know ğŸš¨1ï¸âƒ£ OPERA1ER Cybercrime Group's Leader Arrested: The suspected leader of the cybercrime group OPERA1ER, accused of stealing $30 million through various cybercrime activities, has been apprehended in CÃ´te d'Ivoire by Interpol. This successful operation underscores the crucial role of threat data exchange and collaboration between public and private sector partners.2ï¸âƒ£ Ransomware Hits Japan's Port of Nagoya: In a disruptive incident, the Port of Nagoya in Japan was forced to halt operations due to a ransomware attack attributed to the LockBit 3.0 ransomware group. With the port being a key shipping hub for Toyota, the attack's impact is being closely monitored.3ï¸âƒ£ Mustang Panda Targets European Governments: The Chinese threat group SmugX has been employing an attack vector called HTML Smuggling to plant the PlugX remote access Trojan (RAT) within governmental ministries across Europe. This highlights the necessity for advanced detection measures and increased cybersecurity measures within public entities.4ï¸âƒ£ Microsoft's Potential Ransomware Solution: Microsoft could potentially address ransomware attacks by rate-limiting the ""CreateFile"" API used to access files on Windows. However, implementing this solution would require addressing practical complexities and potential effects on compatibility.5ï¸âƒ£ Critical Fortinet VPN Bug Exploited: Researchers have developed an exploit code for a critical remote code execution vulnerability in Fortinet's FortiGate SSL VPNs. With approximately 340,000 unpatched FortiGate devices vulnerable to the flaw, it's a stern reminder of the need for regular patch updates.6ï¸âƒ£ SSH Servers Hit in 'Proxyjacking' Attacks: Akamai SIRT researchers have discovered a new attack type - proxyjacking, which involves exploiting vulnerable SSH servers to launch Docker services. This clandestine use of network bandwidth for monetary gains further emphasizes the need for constant vigilance and proactive security measures.Spread the word to help raise cybersecurity awareness, and follow if you like this kind of content. Plateforme YARISPlateforme YARIS,"#data#submarine#cable#communication#informationsharing#YarisDid you know that 99% of global data flows are transmitted through undersea cables?Protecting the security of data transmitted through undersea cables is crucial for several reasons:1- undersea cables are the backbone of global communication networks, carrying massive amounts of sensitive information, including financial transactions, personal data, and government communications. Any breach or interception of data can have far-reaching consequences, such as compromising national security or exposing individuals to identity theft.2- undersea cables are vulnerable to physical damage, such as anchor strikes, natural disasters, or intentional sabotage.3- data traffic continues to increase exponentially, and the reliance on undersea cables will only grow. Protecting their security is essential to maintain the trust and integrity of the global digital infrastructure, fostering economic growth, innovation, and international cooperation.The YARIS platform provides secure and reliable communication solutions. It employs advanced encryption algorithms (AES, SSL, TSL, PKI, IPsec) to ensure the confidentiality of the transmitted data. It also utilizes robust authentication mechanisms to verify the integrity and authenticity of the communication endpoints.With its advanced technology and expertise, the YARIS information system helps safeguard undersea data transmission, enabling organizations to securely transfer sensitive information across long distances in the maritime domain.Because of unique features such as collaborative information sharing YARIS facilitates seamless information sharing and collaboration among multiple stakeholders involved in maritime security. It allows government agencies, law enforcement, maritime industry organizations, and international partners to share critical information, intelligence, and incident reports securely and efficiently.This promotes collaboration and improves coordination for effective response and decision-making while leveraging advanced analytics and intelligence capabilities to analyze maritime data and identify patterns, trends, and anomalies. It enables users to gain insights into maritime security risks, identify potential threats, and prioritize response efforts. The use of artificial intelligence and machine learning algorithms enhances the accuracy and efficiency of data analysis.#DataFlows#UnderseaCables#DataSecurityMatters#cybersecurity#datasafety#yaoundearchitecture#maritimedomain#informationsystem#gulfofguinea#gogin#africa#MDA#europeanunion#EU#informationsystem#domainemaritimeMARITIMAFRICAGulf of Guinea Maritime InstituteDr. Ifesinachi O.CRESMAOCRESMACCRESMAO EIMSINTER-REGIONAL COORDINATION CENTREInstitut de SÃ©curitÃ© Maritime InterrÃ©gional - ISMIExpertise FranceExpertise France CÃ´te d'Ivoire (golfe de GuinÃ©e)Fisheries Committee for the West Central Gulf of Guinea (FCWC/CPCO)",1Â 402Â abonnÃ©s1Â 402Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['data', 'submarine', 'cable', 'communication', 'informationsharing', 'Yaris', 'DataFlows', 'UnderseaCables', 'DataSecurityMatters', 'cybersecurity', 'datasafety', 'yaoundearchitecture', 'maritimedomain', 'informationsystem', 'gulfofguinea', 'gogin', 'africa', 'MDA', 'europeanunion', 'EU', 'informationsystem', 'domainemaritime']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Anthony MondiafereAnthony Mondiafere,"The Importance of Cybersecurity in Africa and the Need for Antivirus APIs:In the contemporary digital age, where technology plays a pivotal role in various aspects of life, the importance of cybersecurity cannot be overstated.Protection Against Cyber Threats:Africa, like any other region, faces a diverse range of cyber threats, including malware, ransomware, phishing attacks, and more. Cybersecurity measures, including antivirus solutions, are essential to safeguard personal and sensitive information from unauthorized access and malicious activities.Data Privacy and Confidentiality:With the increasing digitization of personal and business data, ensuring data privacy and confidentiality is paramount. Cybersecurity measures help prevent unauthorized access, data breaches, and identity theft, which are significant concerns in a digitally connected society.Economic Impact:Cybersecurity incidents can have severe economic repercussions, affecting businesses, governments, and individuals alike. Loss of sensitive data, financial fraud, and disruptions to critical infrastructure can lead to financial losses and hamper economic growth. Robust cybersecurity practices mitigate these risks.National Security:In the context of national security, the protection of critical infrastructure such as power grids, communication networks, and financial systems is vital. Cybersecurity measures help prevent cyber-attacks that could potentially compromise national security.Digital Transformation and Development:Africa is experiencing a digital transformation, with increased reliance on technology for education, healthcare, e-commerce, and more. A secure digital environment is fundamental for sustainable development and progress, making cybersecurity a key enabler for positive socio-economic change.Mobile Device Security:Mobile phones are widely used in Africa, often serving as primary devices for communication, banking, and accessing the internet. The implementation of antivirus APIs on phones helps protect against mobile-specific threats, ensuring the security of personal and financial information.Email Security:Emails remain a common vector for cyber-attacks such as phishing. Antivirus APIs integrated into email systems can detect and block malicious attachments, links, and phishing attempts, reducing the risk of users falling victim to cyber scams.Laptop and Computer Security:As laptops and office computers are integral to daily work and business operations, securing these devices is critical. Antivirus solutions provide real-time protection against a wide range of malware, enhancing overall system security.User Awareness and Education:Cybersecurity involves not only technological solutions but also user awareness and education. Promoting a culture of cybersecurity awareness helps individuals and organizations in Africa better understand and mitigate potential risks.#africa#cybersecurityawareness#antivirussoftware",Founder || CEO || EntrepreneurFounder || CEO || Entrepreneur,,,,"['africa', 'cybersecurityawareness', 'antivirussoftware']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Shikana GroupShikana Group,"Our most recent overview of the economic and investment environment in the East African Community (EAC) reveals six noteworthy developments:1. Tanzania is actively seeking to expand its trade relationships, recently engaging with Namibia, Japan, and South Korea. The country has secured over US$8.5 billion in trade deals across various sectors in the past three years.2. The World Bank has approved US$1.2 billion to support Kenya's budget and climate goals. Kenya also plans to invest US$100 million in key African financial institutions.3. Uganda's handicraft sector is growing, thanks to international demand and government support. The sector now employs over 2,000 women and exports to major U.S. retailers.4. Rwanda is set to become a technology hub with the development of Kigali Innovation City, a project expected to generate significant economic activity.5. South Sudan's cement industry is attracting foreign investment, with a Malaysian firm planning to invest US$100 million in a new factory.6. Ethiopia is opening up its aviation sector to private investment, allowing local airlines to offer scheduled flights and encouraging the construction of new airstrips.Continue reading below for in-depth analysis and implications. You can also sign up for our weekly newsletter athttps://lnkd.in/dY57Uz4K.#EastAfrica#Business#News#Investment#Trade#Infrastructure#Tanzania#Kenya#Uganda#Burundi#Rwanda#Aviation#Art#Economy#Africa",1Â 965Â abonnÃ©s1Â 965Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['EastAfrica', 'Business', 'News', 'Investment', 'Trade', 'Infrastructure', 'Tanzania', 'Kenya', 'Uganda', 'Burundi', 'Rwanda', 'Aviation', 'Art', 'Economy', 'Africa']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

author: Babatunde OsadareBabatunde Osadare,"Presidential election in South Africa is underway and a winner is expected to be announced this weekend. Like most elections in Africa, the issues of energy security and load shedding are at the centre of the electoral debates. When compared with Nigeria and most Sub-Saharan countries, the energy access rate and infrastructure are better, even though persistent load shedding have remained a big irritant despite recent improvements.Electoral promises on electricity have also been ceaseless for decades in Nigeria;" and the journey towards reliable electricity for all
content: is still long. Should citizens continue to believe in electoral promises of better electricity experience during each election circle? With decentralization towards State electricity markets under the Electricity Act Act
reactions: a lot more attention will be paid to States political actors to deliver on electricity promises
comments: rather than at the federal level
comments_number: as is the norm.Read the below for more detailed thoughts.#EnergyAccess#ElectricityAct2023#EnergyPolitics#SubSaharanAfrica#SouthAfricanElections""

author: DonÃ© P.DonÃ© P.,"ğŸš¨ Exciting Opportunity Alert! ğŸš¨Join Our Team as an IT Senior Security Analyst in Durban!Must be based in South Africa, and South African Citizen.Are you ready to lead the charge in transforming cybersecurity landscapes and safeguarding digital frontiers? Our esteemed BPO firm is searching for a dynamic and skilled IT Senior Security Analyst to join our vibrant team in Durban. This pivotal role is central to our security operations, offering the chance to shape security architecture, deploy cutting-edge technologies, and spearhead our cyber defense initiatives.What You'll Do:Design and implement robust cyber defense and detection technologies.Partner with IT Operations to address system vulnerabilities with long-term solutions.Develop and refine documentation and reporting standards, ensuring alignment with industry best practices.Lead incident response efforts, ensuring swift resolution and regulatory compliance.Proactively monitor our networks and devices, staying ahead of security threats.Investigate cybersecurity incidents, providing expert analysis and recommendations.Champion our IT security and regulatory compliance efforts, setting new benchmarks in protection.Are You the Right Fit?You possess a relevant IT Security certification or equivalent.You bring a minimum of 5 years' experience in IT systems engineering and at least 3 years in IT security incident response.Your toolkit includes experience with network vulnerability testing, remediation across various technologies, and a solid grasp of firewalls, proxies, SIEM, AV, and IDS/IPS.You're well-versed in cybersecurity documentation, evidence collection, and industry-standard InfoSec tools and techniques.Pentest experience and APT exposure? Africa News BulletinAfrica News Bulletin,"The United States and theEuropean Union(EU) have intensified efforts against maritime crime, designating Kenya as the second country, after Seychelles, to prosecute maritime crime suspects. Concerns over disruptions in Red Sea trade by Yemenâ€™s Houthis and Somali piracy have prompted this move. EU Naval Force (EU Navfor) confirmed Kenya's role in handling maritime crimes alongside Seychelles. EU Ambassador to KenyaHenriette Geigeremphasized collaboration to enhance maritime security. U.S. Africa Command, supporting regional maritime security through its 3D approach (diplomacy, development, defense), recently engaged with officials in Madagascar, Mauritius, and Seychelles.#MaritimeSecurity#Kenya#EU#USAfricaCommand#Piracy#GlobalTrade#MaritimeLaw",4Â 858Â abonnÃ©s4Â 858Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['MaritimeSecurity', 'Kenya', 'EU', 'USAfricaCommand', 'Piracy', 'GlobalTrade', 'MaritimeLaw']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Franck Nelson NIKIEMAFranck Nelson NIKIEMA,"Hello to you dear member of my network, I would like to present to you my vision of cybercrime in Africa through a short video on YouTube. First, let's clear up the theme:ABSTRACTAfrica has been among the fastest growing regions in terms of cybercrimeactivities. The continent is also a source of significant cyberattacks targetingthe rest of the world. However, a number of measures have been taken toaddress cyber-threats and improve cybersecurity in the continent. Manycountries in the continent have developed legislation to fight cyber-threats.They have also strengthened enforcement measures. Private sector effortshave also been undertaken to strengthen cybersecurity.African nations have been increasingly facing the threat of cybercrime over the past few years. Cybercrime emanates from the continent, and threats spread easily as many servers are located there. Africa has become a hub for cybercriminal activity, with cyber attack increases across the continent formulating a threat to digital growth.The short video at the bottom: watch and share as much as possible on social networksThanks in advance.","IngÃ©nieur de Conception en TÃ©lÃ©communications (SpÃ©cialitÃ© : TÃ©lÃ©coms et Services) CFOT,CFOSD & Huawei Datacom CertifiedIngÃ©nieur de Conception en TÃ©lÃ©communications (SpÃ©cialitÃ© : TÃ©lÃ©coms et Services) CFOT,CFOSD & Huawei Datacom Certified",,,,[];;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Sam MuthuiSam Muthui,"The growth of digital technology in Africa is creating a surge in the need for robust cybersecurity strategies for sustainable business growth.#Cybersecurityis no longer only about protecting physical assets and data stored on servers but is also about protecting the intellectual property, reputation and brand of an organization. It is essential to develop strong security protocols backed by technology and monitoring systems to thwart cyber-attacks.#DataProtectionAs technology advances, so do the cyber threats that organizations in Africa must prepare for. With all the new trends and technologies, it is especially important to adopt a#cyberecurityleadership strategy that includes awareness of emerging threats, employee education, up-to-date technology, and data privacy and security processes.Let's discuss - what measures have you taken to build a robust cybersecurity strategy? Share your thoughts on#BusinessGrowthand#DataSecurityin Africa.#CyberSecurityInAfrica#CyberSecurityMatters",Chief Information Security OfficerChief Information Security Officer,,,,"['Cybersecurity', 'DataProtection', 'cyberecurity', 'BusinessGrowth', 'DataSecurity', 'CyberSecurityInAfrica', 'CyberSecurityMatters']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Charles Kojo VandyckCharles Kojo Vandyck,"This opinion piece highlights the impact of cyber-attacks on African governments' digital infrastructure and the urgent need for proactive cybersecurity measures. It highlights the recent cyber-attack on Kenya's eCitizen portal as a wake-up call for governments to safeguard their digital assets and protect sensitive data while ensuring uninterrupted delivery of essential public services.The repercussions of the eCitizen portal cyber-attack affected numerous citizens, disrupting services like passport and visa applications and mobile-money banking. Besides personal and societal distress, there were significant economic consequences, resulting in financial losses for businesses and the national economy. The incident is not isolated, as other African countries, like South Africa, Nigeria, and Egypt, have also faced cyber threats, emphasising the need for collective action against this growing menace.To address these challenges, the article proposes a multi-faceted approach to strengthen Africa's cybersecurity defences. Governments should invest in cutting-edge cybersecurity infrastructure, including advanced technologies, firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and data encryption protocols. Also, fostering a cybersecurity-conscious culture among employees through training and awareness programs can reduce the likelihood of successful attacks.Collaboration with external stakeholders, such as civil society organisations, private sector companies, and cybersecurity experts, is crucial. Public-private partnerships can facilitate the exchange of cybersecurity knowledge, improving the ability to respond to cyber threats effectively.The article emphasises that securing Africa's digital landscape requires a holistic and dynamic approach. Governments, civil society, and the private sector must work together to develop comprehensive cybersecurity strategies and frameworks. Citizens also play a pivotal role by being educated about cybersecurity best practices and being vigilant in detecting and reporting potential threats.The article argues that this collaborative effort will better protect Africa's digital interests and lead to a prosperous future, leveraging the full potential of digital technology while mitigating its inherent risks.#CyberSecurityAfrica#SecureAfricaDigital#ProtectDigitalAssets#AfricaCyberThreats#PublicPrivatePartnership#SecuringDigitalLandscape#CyberAwareAfrica#DigitalProsperityAfrica#CollaborateAgainstThreats#CyberSafeAfrica",Development PractitionerDevelopment Practitioner,,,,"['CyberSecurityAfrica', 'SecureAfricaDigital', 'ProtectDigitalAssets', 'AfricaCyberThreats', 'PublicPrivatePartnership', 'SecuringDigitalLandscape', 'CyberAwareAfrica', 'DigitalProsperityAfrica', 'CollaborateAgainstThreats', 'CyberSafeAfrica']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Sarah LloydSarah Lloyd,"As we see the impact of the severed undersea cables across east Africa, recover from the shock of the $25million cyber fraud in Asia and suffer the bombardment of phishing attempts the reality of cyber risk gets into our face and under our skinâ€¦This reality is particularly stark across the African continent where the huge digital demand and growth potential is coupled with a lack of cybersecurity policies and standards.â€œNot only do criminals exploit vulnerabilities in cybersecurity across the region, but they also take advantage of variations in law enforcement capabilities across physical borders,â€ said Craig Jones, INTERPOLâ€™s Director of Cybercrime.How can we find a balance between technological and digital advancement versus cyber security? How best can we protect ourselves, our finances and our businesses? How do we ensure we are taking the right measures from an individual, corporate and national perspective?",Chief Risk Officer (CRO) at Absa Bank ZambiaChief Risk Officer (CRO) at Absa Bank Zambia,,,,[];;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Prashil GareebPrashil Gareeb,"Today is#AfricaDay. Weâ€™re passionately trying to help African enterprises leapfrog their current IT estate to enable growth, not just survival.Deloitte Africa says more than 89% of African organisations experienced a cyber incident in the past year, yet clients we talk to still run separate network and security postures. Our observation is that networks are largely still MPLS, and cloud architectures are evolving back to hybrid due to sovereignty concerns.Skills, refocus of IT budgets and technical debt are discouraging network modernisation, which ironically (like in the rest of world), has commoditised and become less attractive for investment, discouraged by our geo diversity and despite our less than mature terrestrial, wireless and undersea networks.Weâ€™re not giving up. Gartnerâ€™s suggestion that 40% or more of African businesses have either moved or considering moving to SASE is encouraging. Our goal is thus to help clients technically, operationally and commercially transform to managed networking, solving for the challenges. This then allows them to focus up the stack, and make long outstanding investments.Hereâ€™s my blog with more detail.https://lnkd.in/gU2be3yCHappy to connect.",Vice-President of Managed Networking & Collaboration Services | Strategic LeadershipVice-President of Managed Networking & Collaboration Services | Strategic Leadership,,,,['AfricaDay'];;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Communications Africa/AfriqueCommunications Africa/Afrique,"African organisations face higher susceptibility to phishing attacks, with a 36.7% Phish-prone Percentage (PPP) compared to the global average of 34.3%.KnowBe4's 2024 report highlights the need for robust security awareness training to mitigate cyber risks in Africa.""Cybersecurity challenges in Africa require a combination of regulation, guidelines and security awareness training. Particular focus is needed on threats like deepfakes used for political manipulation, especially ahead of major elections in various African countries. More public-private partnerships are essential to build capacity, address the skills shortage, and improve resilience in the digital world. Aguna SolutionsAguna Solutions,"Phishing attacks are not new, but they have become more sophisticated and aggressive in recent years. Phishing is a type of fraud that uses malicious emails to trick people into revealing their personal information. The fraudsters can use this information for identity theft and other financial crimes.Phishing kits, like Greatness, make it easy for anyone to launch a phishing attack. The platform provides affiliates with attachment and link builders to create decoy and login pages for Microsoft 365, with features such as pre-filled email addresses, company logos, and background images. Greatness has been used to target manufacturing, healthcare, and technology entities in the U.S., U.K., Australia, South Africa, and Canada, with activity spiking in December 2022 and March 2023.As cyber threats continue to rise, it's crucial to have robust web and email protection to safeguard not only your personal but your business's sensitive information. Aguna Solutions web and email protection solutions are designed to detect and prevent a wide range of cyber threats, including phishing attacks, malware infections, and spam. Our ability to provide customized solutions tailored to your businessâ€™s unique needs can help you identify and block threats before they can cause any harm to your organization.Reach out to us athttps://lnkd.in/dNrKD6pu#IT#ITsolutions#Aguna#phishing#phishingattacks",175Â abonnÃ©s175Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['IT', 'ITsolutions', 'Aguna', 'phishing', 'phishingattacks']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

amaDigital IT SolutionsamaDigital IT Solutions,"Understanding Phishing Scams âš”ï¸As businesses in South Africa, it's crucial to understand and protect your organization from phishing scams, a prevalent form of cybercrime. Phishing scams typically involve fraudulent emails or messages appearing to be from reputable sources to trick individuals into revealing sensitive information such as:- Usernames- Passwords- Credit card detailsWhat to look out for:- Unexpected requests- Poor grammar- Misspelt URLs.These scams are increasingly sophisticated and often target businesses. To protect your organization, educate your staff about the signs of phishing. Implement stringent email and internet usage policies on company devices and consider investing in advanced email filtering and threat detection software. Remember, vigilance and education are your first lines of defense against phishing scams.Give us a call to discuss how we can add value to your business: 011 568 0300#CyberSecurity#Phising#ITtechncian#MangedServiceProvider#email",498Â abonnÃ©s498Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['CyberSecurity', 'Phising', 'ITtechncian', 'MangedServiceProvider', 'email']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Stephen TurksonStephen Turkson,"Awareness for Online Shoppers in Africa - Phishing AttacksPhishing attacks are a form of social engineering attack in which hackers try to deceive targets into disclosing personal information or granting entry to private networks or systems. The information may be private (such as monetary or social security numbers) or commercial (such as trade secrets, corporate plans, information, or credentials). If permitted access, the attackers can then download malware and utilize the victims' computers to launch other attacks. 90% of data breaches are caused by phishing, which is one of the biggest cybersecurity hazards. 83% of firms reported experiencing phishing assaults. A company must spend more money to recuperate from an attack that is successful.Online buyers should be cautious about scams such as phishing since they are particularly susceptible to them. Online customers must be aware of the dangers posed by phishing and take precautions to safeguard themselves.Recognizing the symptoms of a phishing assault is among the most crucial action that online shoppers can take. These include emails that beg for personal information, including strange links or attachments, or look to be from a reliable source but really contain spelling or language errors.Phishing attacks can occur by email, social media, phone, or text messages, among other channels. It's possible for the caller, message, or financial institution to make this claim. They can insist that they require your login information, credit card information, password, or other details immediately. They can assert that you have won something or owe money. They can be masquerading as an official or charitable organization. They can claim that they require the knowledge to thwart an immediate threat, such as a virus or hacking. They might act as anyone from your IT staff or from a department higher up in your company who desperately requires permission to utilize a network or critical information.#cybersecurity",Research Fellow - Academic thesis and dissertations writingsResearch Fellow - Academic thesis and dissertations writings,,,,['cybersecurity'];;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Aliyu Ibrahim UsmanAliyu Ibrahim Usman,"Navigating the Evolving Threat Landscape: Cyberattacks in AfricaAfrican nations and businesses are experiencing a surge in cyberattacks. As the continent embraces digital transformation, vulnerabilities are emerging. Here's a breakdown of the current cyber threats facing Africa:Social Engineering: Phishing scams and other manipulative tactics are prevalent due to lower cybersecurity awareness.Weak Infrastructure: Many businesses lack robust cybersecurity protocols, creating easy targets for attackers.Data Security Concerns: The rise of e-commerce and digital services necessitates strong data protection measures.The impact is significant:Financial Losses: Cyber crime costs African countries billions annually, hindering economic growth.Disrupted Services: Critical infrastructure and essential services can be crippled by successful attacks.Eroded Trust: Businesses hesitant to embrace e-commerce due to security fears.Stay vigilant! Here are some resources to learn more and fortify your defenses:The African Union (AU) Convention on Cybersecurity and Data Protection (https://lnkd.in/dQF88356)Let's discuss how to build a more secure digital future for Africa in the comments below!",Founder & CEO @ Cyber Cadets Academy | Hacker | MentorFounder & CEO @ Cyber Cadets Academy | Hacker | Mentor,,,,[];;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

author: Check Point Software AfricaCheck Point Software Africa,"An organization in Africa has been attacked on average 1914 times per week in the last 6 months, compared to 1131 attacks per organization globally.The most targeted country in Africa is Mauritius. The most common vulnerability exploit type in Africa is Remote Code Execution, impacting 61% of the organizations.Below are more insights from ThreatCloud Threat Map. author: AGERPRESAGERPRES,"#news#Uraine#Moldova#ECC2023#Romania#cybersecurityAGERPRES most important news in brief on Wednesday, 30 August 2023Qakbot malware computer programme's infrastructure, partially dismantled by Romanian anti-terrorism directorateThe Directorate for the Investigation of Organized Crime and Terrorism prosecutors and the police have dismantled, at the request of the US authorities, part of the infrastructure of the Qakbot malware computer programme. The investigations carried out showed that, between October 2021 and April 2023, the administrators would have received almost 54 million euros from the ransoms that were paid by the victims. The analysis of the confiscated infrastructure showed that the malware would have infected more than 700,000 of computers around the world, and the authorities have detected servers infected with Qakbot in almost 30 countries in Europe, South and North America, Asia and Africa, enabling the malware's activity on a global scale.https://lnkd.in/dXNgXdwY",768Â abonnÃ©s768Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['news', 'Uraine', 'Moldova', 'ECC2023', 'Romania', 'cybersecurity']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;
