Charles Kojo VandyckCharles Kojo Vandyck,"This opinion piece highlights the impact of cyber-attacks on African governments' digital infrastructure and the urgent need for proactive cybersecurity measures. It highlights the recent cyber-attack on Kenya's eCitizen portal as a wake-up call for governments to safeguard their digital assets and protect sensitive data while ensuring uninterrupted delivery of essential public services.The repercussions of the eCitizen portal cyber-attack affected numerous citizens, disrupting services like passport and visa applications and mobile-money banking. Besides personal and societal distress, there were significant economic consequences, resulting in financial losses for businesses and the national economy. The incident is not isolated, as other African countries, like South Africa, Nigeria, and Egypt, have also faced cyber threats, emphasising the need for collective action against this growing menace.To address these challenges, the article proposes a multi-faceted approach to strengthen Africa's cybersecurity defences. Governments should invest in cutting-edge cybersecurity infrastructure, including advanced technologies, firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and data encryption protocols. Also, fostering a cybersecurity-conscious culture among employees through training and awareness programs can reduce the likelihood of successful attacks.Collaboration with external stakeholders, such as civil society organisations, private sector companies, and cybersecurity experts, is crucial. Public-private partnerships can facilitate the exchange of cybersecurity knowledge, improving the ability to respond to cyber threats effectively.The article emphasises that securing Africa's digital landscape requires a holistic and dynamic approach. Governments, civil society, and the private sector must work together to develop comprehensive cybersecurity strategies and frameworks. Citizens also play a pivotal role by being educated about cybersecurity best practices and being vigilant in detecting and reporting potential threats.The article argues that this collaborative effort will better protect Africa's digital interests and lead to a prosperous future, leveraging the full potential of digital technology while mitigating its inherent risks.#CyberSecurityAfrica#SecureAfricaDigital#ProtectDigitalAssets#AfricaCyberThreats#PublicPrivatePartnership#SecuringDigitalLandscape#CyberAwareAfrica#DigitalProsperityAfrica#CollaborateAgainstThreats#CyberSafeAfrica",Development PractitionerDevelopment Practitioner,,,,"['CyberSecurityAfrica', 'SecureAfricaDigital', 'ProtectDigitalAssets', 'AfricaCyberThreats', 'PublicPrivatePartnership', 'SecuringDigitalLandscape', 'CyberAwareAfrica', 'DigitalProsperityAfrica', 'CollaborateAgainstThreats', 'CyberSafeAfrica']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Communications Africa/AfriqueCommunications Africa/Afrique,"African organisations face higher susceptibility to phishing attacks, with a 36.7% Phish-prone Percentage (PPP) compared to the global average of 34.3%.KnowBe4's 2024 report highlights the need for robust security awareness training to mitigate cyber risks in Africa.""Cybersecurity challenges in Africa require a combination of regulation, guidelines and security awareness training. Particular focus is needed on threats like deepfakes used for political manipulation, especially ahead of major elections in various African countries. More public-private partnerships are essential to build capacity, address the skills shortage, and improve resilience in the digital world. Investing in Africaâ€™s youth and providing cybersecurity training opportunities can fill the skills gap and also address youth unemployment,"" remarked Anna Collard, senior vice-president of content strategy & evangelist Africa at KnowBe4.Read more:https://zurl.co/bzSi#Cybersecurity#Africa#PhishingAwareness",388Â abonnÃ©s388Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['Cybersecurity', 'Africa', 'PhishingAwareness']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Communications Africa/AfriqueCommunications Africa/Afrique,"How is Check Point addressing the cybersecurity skills shortage, particularly in Africa?A leading provider of cybersecurity solutions globally,Check Point Software Technologies Ltd., has partnered with theCyberSafe Foundation, a non-governmental organization in Africa, to tackle the ongoing cybersecurity skills gap. Through Check Point's SecureAcademy program, this collaboration aims to support Cybersafe's CyberGirls initiative, providing free cutting-edge cybersecurity education to women aged 18 to 28. This initiative not only empowers women with technical skills but also closes the gender gap in the industry and uplifts underserved communities in Africa, while combatting the rising threat of cybercrime.â€œWe are extremely proud of the impact our programs have had on the lives of many of our fellows, helping young women gain access to life changing opportunities,â€ stated Confidence Staveley, the founder and executive director Cybersafe Foundation. ""Our partnership with Check Point will contribute immensely to our disruptive educational model by providing free quality cybersecurity training to the CyberGirls community.""Pankaj Bhula, regional director, Africa at Check Point added, â€œEducation is fundamental to combating the increasing volume of cybercrime both at home and abroad. Partnerships such as this one is key in closing the skills gap and helping to create a future employee pipeline in the cybersecurity sector. We are thrilled to be partnering with an organisation that has had so much success in not only this aspect, but also one which has made a real impact on the lives of their fellows through upskilling and education.â€Read more:https://lnkd.in/euPcXhzP#EmpowerWomen#CyberSecurity#AfricaTech",388Â abonnÃ©s388Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['EmpowerWomen', 'CyberSecurity', 'AfricaTech']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Ousmane TOUREOusmane TOURE,"â€¢ SENSIBILISATION CYBERSÃ‰CURITÃ‰ EN AFRIQUELa cybersÃ©curitÃ© en Afrique est confrontÃ©e Ã  des dÃ©fis majeurs, avec des exemples rÃ©cents de compromissions qui soulignent lâ€™urgence dâ€™une action concertÃ©e. Enfin, au Kenya, des cybercriminels ont rÃ©ussi Ã  infiltrer le systÃ¨me de paiement mobile, compromettant des donnÃ©es sensibles et causant des pertes financiÃ¨res importantes.Ces incidents dÃ©montrent que les cyberattaques ne connaissent pas de frontiÃ¨res et peuvent toucher tous les secteurs, des institutions gouvernementales aux entreprises privÃ©es. author: Ange Mickael TREKEAnge Mickael TREKE,"ğŸ’¡ La cybersÃ©curitÃ©: un enjeu majeur en AfriqueL'Afrique est le continent qui connaÃ®t la croissance la plus rapide en termes d'adoption d'Internet. Cette croissance s'accompagne d'une augmentation des cyberattaques, qui constituent un enjeu majeur pour les entreprises et les gouvernements africains.Les cybercriminels profitent de la faiblesse des systÃ¨mes de sÃ©curitÃ© informatique en Afrique pour cibler des organisations et des individus. Ils utilisent des techniques variÃ©es, telles que le phishing, les ransomwares, les attaques DDoS et le vol de donnÃ©es, pour nuire Ã  leurs victimes.Les cyberattaques peuvent avoir des consÃ©quences importantes, tant sur le plan financier que sur le plan opÃ©rationnel. Elles peuvent entraÃ®ner des pertes de donnÃ©es, des perturbations des activitÃ©s, et des dommages Ã  la rÃ©putation.Dans certains cas, les cyberattaques peuvent mÃªme avoir des consÃ©quences plus graves, telles que la violation de la vie privÃ©e ou la diffusion de fausses informations (fake news).Face Ã  ce flÃ©au, des acteurs internationaux tels queKaspersky,SearchInformetHillstone Networksse sont positionnÃ©es pour accompagner les organisations en Afrique en matiÃ¨re de lutte contre la cybercriminalitÃ©, protection des donnÃ©es et sÃ©curitÃ© informatique.Kasperskya prÃªtÃ© main forte Ã  INTERPOL en lui fournissant des donnÃ©es de renseignement sur les menaces dans le cadre de son opÃ©ration Africa Cyber Surge II, qui a permis aux enquÃªteurs d'identifier des infrastructures compromises et d'apprÃ©hender des acteurs de la menace prÃ©sumÃ©s dans tout le continent africain. Initiative Repenser la SecuritÃ© en AfriqueInitiative Repenser la SecuritÃ© en Afrique,"MESSAGE FROM THE COORDINATOR OF THE NETWORK RETHINKING SECURITY IN AFRICADear members of the Rethinking Security in Africa (RSA) network,I wanted to share a few words with you as coordinator of this essential network. First of all, I would like to thank you for your commitment and your contribution to the promotion of security and peace in Africa.Our network plays a crucial role in the search for innovative and sustainable solutions to respond to the security challenges facing our continent. Thanks to our discussions and collaborations, we have been able to develop a better understanding of security issues and seek to implement concrete initiatives to resolve them.I would also like to emphasize the importance of the diversity of our network. The different actors that we can bring together - researchers, policy makers, members of civil society, representatives of security forces - bring unique perspectives that enrich our discussions and our actions. This diversity allows us to take into account the different needs and realities of our countries while promoting multidimensional approaches to security.In the months to come, we will continue to work together to promote and above all rethink security and peace in Africa in accordance with and respect for the objectives of the APSA (African Peace and Security Architecture). Our network will continue to organize conferences, workshops and working groups to share best practices, knowledge and assessments in the field of security. We will also encourage the creation of partnerships between different actors and institutions in order to strengthen the effectiveness of our initiatives.In conclusion, I am extremely proud of what we have accomplished so far, but I know there is still much to do. Together, we can continue to rethink and reinvent security in Africa for a safer and more peaceful future.Thank you all for your commitment and valuable contribution.Yours sincerely,The coordinator of the Rethinking Security in Africa networkMarie Noelle Koyara",1Â abonnÃ©1Â abonnÃ©,,,,[];;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Andrea LundhAndrea Lundh,"TheForbes AfriqueApril May 2024 Edition is just released. The editors took the audacious step to dedicate ample space to an issue gaining more and more attention from so many various angles: Food Security in Africa.I was asked to contribute a couple of pieces and I was happy and honored to contribute to thisÂ edition alongside other contributors likeDaouda Sembene, PhDandAbdoul Salam Belloamong others.I have provided aÂ general articleÂ in the form of an introduction to the issue of food security in Africa and the challenges it pauses to the continent. Citing the definition of food security as adopted by theFAO,Â I aimed at replacing the topic within a broader context especially with regard to African realities.What motivated me to contribute this general introduction is the fact that rarely agronomists are offered an opportunity to address the general public on such a crucial issue.Having been educated at bothÂ atSLU - Sveriges lantbruksuniversitet(Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences),Â and Hollandâ€™sWageningen University & Research, I was made aware very early of the holisticÂ dimensionÂ of food science and how critical is to always replace food security in its human, community, social and economic context.Although my approach is broad, I thought it serves the purpose of raising awareness among the Forbes Afrique distinguished readership about these crucial matters.Â I mentioned how food security is becoming aÂ national security issueÂ with multiple consequences and impact on human, social, economic, strategic and geopolitical levels.The second article I was invited to contribute is in the form of a focus on the sensitive issue ofÂ food security indexing in Africa. There, I submitted the need for new indicators in structuring new metrics in ranking several African countries and measuring their levels of self-reliance, capacity in coping with climate-induced disruptions, resilience to risks and price fluctuations, gender equality progress, among other indicators.Of course, I am grateful for all those who are helping us developing the new food security index driven by theStockholm Initiative for Food Security. A special mention goes to the research staff atMo Ibrahim Foundationand also toÂ ProfessorKamel Jedidifrom Columbia Business School for his generous technical assistance in statistics and marketing.If there is a single message to pass on here I would articulate it as follows:-    Food insecurity is the single most urgent challenge to face in Africa today in view of the dire consequences derived from hunger and famine.-    No sustainable solution will face off this problem without the involvement of the African communities themselves. Solutions to food insecurity on the continent will not come from foreign land.-     Food sits at the center of all developmental questions. Only a comprehensive approach will lead to structurally sound and locally coherent food systems.",Agronomist/Researcher/EssayistAgronomist/Researcher/Essayist,,,,"['ForbesAfrique', 'FoodSecurity', 'SÃ©curitÃ©Alimentaire', 'Enjeux', 'DÃ©fis', 'Tribune']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Bangaly KabaBangaly Kaba,"The importance of Information and Communication Technologies (ICTs) as the internet in the global information society cannot be exaggerated. Africa needs access to robust information and communication tools to acquire the resources and efficiency essential for sustainable development. That is why the President Houphouet Boigny stated three decades ago:â€œAfrica missed the industrial revolution, and it cannot afford to stand aside and let the communication revolution go by, too.â€Unfortunately, internet use is still lagging despite the widespread diffusion of mobile technologies throughout the continent. Instead of addressing the issue, a government somewhere in the region deliberately restricted internet and related media access, preventing its inhabitants from participating and benefiting from our information society. People use unsafe means to access a few media, potentially exposing them to the most critical cyber risks.Can anyone explain to me what could be a good idea for such an endeavor? My studies and many others clearly showed the positive impacts of internet-based communications technology on knowledge creation and dissemination, the rise of digital entrepreneurship, free speech, oversight of political wrongdoing, etc. The list is endless. Of course, I do not deny a few unintended consequences inherent to all human creations, but they largely underweight the limitless advantages of emerging digital communication technologies, especially in African countries. This arbitrary restriction is not happening in Cote dâ€™Ivoire, and again, thank you, President Ouattara, for not compromising the competitiveness of his beautiful country, even though his government is a victim of the most severe attacks on social media.Â French will follow:PrÃ©sident Ouattara et le cas de Cote dâ€™Ivoire, est un cas dâ€™Ã©cole. Il y a des prÃ©alables Ã  la fourniture et a lâ€™Ã©closion des nouvelles technologies de lâ€™information et de la communication et parmi celles-ci, figure lâ€™Ã©nergie dont lâ€™Ã©lectricitÃ©. Sous le leadership dâ€™ADO, le pays a atteint une couverture oscillant entre 80 et 90% de dÃ©serte en Ã©lectricitÃ©, un taux Ã©galÃ© par aucun autre pays en Afrique Sub-Saharienne mÃªme pas le Nigeria. Je comprends difficilement les critiques acerbes surtout Ã  lâ€™interne Ã  lâ€™endroit de ce bÃ¢tisseur hors pair contemporain. Ceci rappelle bien la formule utilisÃ©e une fois par le premier ministre dâ€™alors du QuÃ©bec, Daniel Johnson, dans les annÃ©es 60, et qui se plaisait Ã  dire Â«Quand je me regarde, je me dÃ©sole;" quand je me compare
content: je me consoleÂ».""

Communications Africa/AfriqueCommunications Africa/Afrique,"How are cyber threats evolving in Africa for 2024?Kaspersky's recent insights shed light: cybercrime continues its surge across the continent. In South Africa alone, IoT attacks skyrocketed by 28% in Q3 2023. Meanwhile, phishing attacks surged by 134%, a worrisome trend seen in other regions too. Notably, Africa witnesses significant attacks on industrial control systems (ICS), impacting crucial sectors like energy and manufacturing.What's the advice? Kaspersky's principal cybersecurity researcher,David Emmemphasises proactive measures: anticipate state-sponsored cyber-attacks and an AI-driven surge in spear-phishing. To counter these, businesses must adopt robust technologies like threat feeds, advanced security systems, and incident response solutions. It's time to fortify defenses against evolving cyber threats!Read more:https://zurl.co/rfOn#KasperskyInsights#CyberThreatsAfrica#CyberSecurity",388Â abonnÃ©s388Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['KasperskyInsights', 'CyberThreatsAfrica', 'CyberSecurity']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

This effort aims to educate the community about a wide range of cyber risks and threats.Pour rappel le programme ambassadeur numÃ©rique vise Ã  sensibiliser les citoyens aux risques liÃ©s Ã  l'utilisation d'Internet et Ã  leur fournir des outils pour se protÃ©ger contre les cybermenaces. Il comprend des campagnes et des ateliers de sensibilisation sur la cybersÃ©curitÃ©.#Cyber221inspire la jeunesse africaine.Adja Fatou Elisabeth KouassiIBRAHIM DIABATEğŸ†Leaders SÃ©nÃ©galais LeadSenLinda GichohiFaridatou RouambaBalkiss OuedraogoVeda W.Divin BAYONNE#Cyber221#Cyberkarangue",3Â 104Â abonnÃ©s3Â 104Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['Cyber221', 'Cyber221', 'Cyberkarangue']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Antoine RenauxAntoine Renaux,"ğŸŒ Understanding Societal Warfare ğŸŒSocietal warfare is a low-intensity, non-kinetic war in peacetime that relies on non-military means and aims to exploit internal contradictions within the targeted model. It seeks to undermine the fundamentals of a state or society.There are three main arenas:- The State- The Economy- The Societal sphereThe fundamental mechanisms include:- Altering individual perceptions of reality- Delegitimizing authority- Exacerbating radicalizationIt is an exceptionally complex and subjective form of conflict, often indistinguishable from domestic socio-political contestation, and tends to escalate with technological advancements.#SocietalWarfare#LowIntensityConflict#Security#PSYOPS#PoliticalWarfare","Analyste Intelligence Ã©conomique & gÃ©opolitique; DÃ©fense

Marco F.Marco F.,"My latest report on the SahelAbstract:Jihadis groups operating in the Sahel have developed combat techniques that imply the use of motorbikes to surprise government forces deployed in the territory. Motorbikes allow them to carry out rapid attacks and to disappear swiftly after. Confronted with a fast-moving lightweight enemy, the armies of the Sahelian countries and the forces of the international coalitions, are ill equipped and are not able to move as fast. Even air cover is, most of the times, inefficient against flocks of motorbikes that scatter under the cover of forests and bushes.Confrontations between security forces and terrorists take place, in most cases, in locations where specific conditions are met. These conditions are offered for example by forests, for cover, hills, for rapidly vanishing into paths that cannot be taken by four-wheeled vehicles, and rivers that, when crossed, allow the terrorists to gain significant distance and time on their pursuers. In the Sahel, there are numerous examples of these natural characteristics near the borders between two or more countries. One of the most important of these areas is the Liptako-Gourma region, also known as the Sahel tri-border area. Fighters of various affiliation that engage in combat, often receive reinforcements that come from a neighbouring country. Reinforcements are able to cover important distances in a relatively short time onboard motorcycles or pickups.Terrorist groups' characteristics vary. Sometimes, motorcycles are escorted and supported by pickups. Some other times, groups converge to an established rally point, and, only then, when they have reached a certain number of members, launch their attack. Reading these characteristics can help security forces understand the probable affiliation of the group and, most importantly, their intentions. Terrorists seem to be procuring their motorbikes by stealing them from the local population or by looting premises of government administration or military bases, and also, by smuggling them mainly from Nigeria and Togo.#sahel#mobility#insurgent#terrorism#counterterrorism#insurgency#mali#burkinafaso#nigeria#niger#chad#westafrica#nationalsecurity#borders","Google Analytics Cert Click on my profile, ""more"" and ""connect""Google Analytics Cert Click on my profile, ""more"" and ""connect""",,,,"['sahel', 'mobility', 'insurgent', 'terrorism', 'counterterrorism', 'insurgency', 'mali', 'burkinafaso', 'nigeria', 'niger', 'chad', 'westafrica', 'nationalsecurity', 'borders']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Communications Africa/AfriqueCommunications Africa/Afrique,"South African operators joinGSMAOpen Gateway initiative, introducing Number Verification & SIM Swap APIs at MWC 2024. Aimed at combating the 24% surge in digital banking fraud reported in 2022, these standardised APIs empower mobile commerce and financial institutions to enhance user security and mitigate cyber threats. Developers can seamlessly integrate Number Verification for strong authentication and SIM Swap to prevent account takeover attacks. Communications Africa/AfriqueCommunications Africa/Afrique,"African organisations face higher susceptibility to phishing attacks, with a 36.7% Phish-prone Percentage (PPP) compared to the global average of 34.3%.KnowBe4's 2024 report highlights the need for robust security awareness training to mitigate cyber risks in Africa.""Cybersecurity challenges in Africa require a combination of regulation, guidelines and security awareness training. Particular focus is needed on threats like deepfakes used for political manipulation, especially ahead of major elections in various African countries. More public-private partnerships are essential to build capacity, address the skills shortage, and improve resilience in the digital world. Investing in Africaâ€™s youth and providing cybersecurity training opportunities can fill the skills gap and also address youth unemployment,"" remarked Anna Collard, senior vice-president of content strategy & evangelist Africa at KnowBe4.Read more:https://zurl.co/bzSi#Cybersecurity#Africa#PhishingAwareness",388Â abonnÃ©s388Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['Cybersecurity', 'Africa', 'PhishingAwareness']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Amne Suedi Avocate Entrepreneur / Investissements en AfriqueAmne Suedi Avocate Entrepreneur / Investissements en Afrique,"The Personal Data Protection Act of 2022 has been long overdue in Tanzania and finally the law is here.Having been on M&A transactions with gaming and technology companies in Tanzania where we faced big hurdles and had to crack our heads about how to go around the prohibition transfer and sale of database, prohibited under TCRA regulations, this law now allows for transfer and trading of database of personal data and only requirement where the transfer is to companies outside of Tanzania is that the country in which the company is located has adequate protection of personal data.#africa#investmentopportunities#law#data#technology#gaming#investmentadvice","Avocate en droit international / Ressources Naturelles, Technologie et Private Equity / Politique/ Investissement en Afrique/ Experience au Conseil d'AdministrationAvocate en droit international / Ressources Naturelles, Technologie et Private Equity / Politique/ Investissement en Afrique/ Experience au Conseil d'Administration",,,,"['africa', 'investmentopportunities', 'law', 'data', 'technology', 'gaming', 'investmentadvice']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Bangaly KabaBangaly Kaba,"The importance of Information and Communication Technologies (ICTs) as the internet in the global information society cannot be exaggerated. Africa needs access to robust information and communication tools to acquire the resources and efficiency essential for sustainable development. That is why the President Houphouet Boigny stated three decades ago:â€œAfrica missed the industrial revolution, and it cannot afford to stand aside and let the communication revolution go by, too.â€Unfortunately, internet use is still lagging despite the widespread diffusion of mobile technologies throughout the continent. Instead of addressing the issue, a government somewhere in the region deliberately restricted internet and related media access, preventing its inhabitants from participating and benefiting from our information society. People use unsafe means to access a few media, potentially exposing them to the most critical cyber risks.Can anyone explain to me what could be a good idea for such an endeavor? My studies and many others clearly showed the positive impacts of internet-based communications technology on knowledge creation and dissemination, the rise of digital entrepreneurship, free speech, oversight of political wrongdoing, etc. The list is endless. Of course, I do not deny a few unintended consequences inherent to all human creations, but they largely underweight the limitless advantages of emerging digital communication technologies, especially in African countries. This arbitrary restriction is not happening in Cote dâ€™Ivoire, and again, thank you, President Ouattara, for not compromising the competitiveness of his beautiful country, even though his government is a victim of the most severe attacks on social media.Â French will follow:PrÃ©sident Ouattara et le cas de Cote dâ€™Ivoire, est un cas dâ€™Ã©cole. Il y a des prÃ©alables Ã  la fourniture et a lâ€™Ã©closion des nouvelles technologies de lâ€™information et de la communication et parmi celles-ci, figure lâ€™Ã©nergie dont lâ€™Ã©lectricitÃ©. Sous le leadership dâ€™ADO, le pays a atteint une couverture oscillant entre 80 et 90% de dÃ©serte en Ã©lectricitÃ©, un taux Ã©galÃ© par aucun autre pays en Afrique Sub-Saharienne mÃªme pas le Nigeria. Je comprends difficilement les critiques acerbes surtout Ã  lâ€™interne Ã  lâ€™endroit de ce bÃ¢tisseur hors pair contemporain. Ceci rappelle bien la formule utilisÃ©e une fois par le premier ministre dâ€™alors du QuÃ©bec, Daniel Johnson, dans les annÃ©es 60, et qui se plaisait Ã  dire Â«Quand je me regarde, je me dÃ©sole;" quand je me compare
content: je me consoleÂ».""

Communications Africa/AfriqueCommunications Africa/Afrique,"How are cyber threats evolving in Africa for 2024?Kaspersky's recent insights shed light: cybercrime continues its surge across the continent. In South Africa alone, IoT attacks skyrocketed by 28% in Q3 2023. Meanwhile, phishing attacks surged by 134%, a worrisome trend seen in other regions too. Notably, Africa witnesses significant attacks on industrial control systems (ICS), impacting crucial sectors like energy and manufacturing.What's the advice? Kaspersky's principal cybersecurity researcher,David Emmemphasises proactive measures: anticipate state-sponsored cyber-attacks and an AI-driven surge in spear-phishing. To counter these, businesses must adopt robust technologies like threat feeds, advanced security systems, and incident response solutions. It's time to fortify defenses against evolving cyber threats!Read more:https://zurl.co/rfOn#KasperskyInsights#CyberThreatsAfrica#CyberSecurity",388Â abonnÃ©s388Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['KasperskyInsights', 'CyberThreatsAfrica', 'CyberSecurity']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Cyber221Cyber221,"Le programme ambassadeur numÃ©rique pour une Afrique cyber rÃ©siliente.Nous voilÃ  au Botswana avec notre ambassadeur numÃ©riqueHappy Amon.Happy Amonis an IT Expert, with over 15years in the IT / CyberSecurity fields, spending most of her career in Information TechnologyAdministration and Cyber Security Consultation.She is a member of the The International Association of Privacy Professionalsand holds qualifications such as Bachelor of Information Systems, MSCCyber Security, Global IT Course (Information Security & CyberSecurity), Certified Chief Information Security Officer v1 (CCISO),Computer Hacker Forensic Investigator (CHFI), Certified InformationSystems Security Professional (CISSP), Operations Management,Certified Cloud Security Professional (CCSP), Certified InformationSystems Security Professional (CISSP), CCNP Route at Cisco Networking, ITIL V3 Foundation, Administering Microsoft SQL Server 2012Databases, Ethical Hacking ,CCNA Security and CCNA.She maintains an exceptional track record of excellent experiencethroughout her work experience from multinational companies in theareas of IT Administration, Network administration, Pen-Test, PolicyCreation, Risk Assessment & Management, Security Assessments, Auditor Security Governance and Compliance.Capitalizing on her proven expertise and hands on experience inexecuting security governance, risk assessments, compliance,conducting security audits, assessing effectiveness of controls, dataprivacy, incident response, cyber operations,Happy Amonhas decidedto strive to continually rise cyber security awareness as aCyber221Digital Ambassador as voluntary work, to provide the governmentalsector, NGOs, schools and the technical communities with herexperience and knowledge in the field.She firmly believes that a secure cyberspace is a key factor in supporting the economy. As the Botswana National Cyber Security Strategy focuses on bolstering the country's defenses against cyber-attacks, she has taken the opportunity to contribute to enhancing the nation's cyber security capabilities. Additionally, she is actively engaged in promoting cyber security awareness among the general public. This effort aims to educate the community about a wide range of cyber risks and threats.Pour rappel le programme ambassadeur numÃ©rique vise Ã  sensibiliser les citoyens aux risques liÃ©s Ã  l'utilisation d'Internet et Ã  leur fournir des outils pour se protÃ©ger contre les cybermenaces. Il comprend des campagnes et des ateliers de sensibilisation sur la cybersÃ©curitÃ©.#Cyber221inspire la jeunesse africaine.Adja Fatou Elisabeth KouassiIBRAHIM DIABATEğŸ†Leaders SÃ©nÃ©galais LeadSenLinda GichohiFaridatou RouambaBalkiss OuedraogoVeda W.Divin BAYONNE#Cyber221#Cyberkarangue",3Â 104Â abonnÃ©s3Â 104Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['Cyber221', 'Cyber221', 'Cyberkarangue']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Antoine RenauxAntoine Renaux,"ğŸŒ Understanding Societal Warfare ğŸŒSocietal warfare is a low-intensity, non-kinetic war in peacetime that relies on non-military means and aims to exploit internal contradictions within the targeted model. It seeks to undermine the fundamentals of a state or society.There are three main arenas:- The State- The Economy- The Societal sphereThe fundamental mechanisms include:- Altering individual perceptions of reality- Delegitimizing authority- Exacerbating radicalizationIt is an exceptionally complex and subjective form of conflict, often indistinguishable from domestic socio-political contestation, and tends to escalate with technological advancements.#SocietalWarfare#LowIntensityConflict#Security#PSYOPS#PoliticalWarfare","Analyste Intelligence Ã©conomique & gÃ©opolitique; DÃ©fense

Marco F.Marco F.,"My latest report on the SahelAbstract:Jihadis groups operating in the Sahel have developed combat techniques that imply the use of motorbikes to surprise government forces deployed in the territory. Motorbikes allow them to carry out rapid attacks and to disappear swiftly after. Confronted with a fast-moving lightweight enemy, the armies of the Sahelian countries and the forces of the international coalitions, are ill equipped and are not able to move as fast. Even air cover is, most of the times, inefficient against flocks of motorbikes that scatter under the cover of forests and bushes.Confrontations between security forces and terrorists take place, in most cases, in locations where specific conditions are met. These conditions are offered for example by forests, for cover, hills, for rapidly vanishing into paths that cannot be taken by four-wheeled vehicles, and rivers that, when crossed, allow the terrorists to gain significant distance and time on their pursuers. In the Sahel, there are numerous examples of these natural characteristics near the borders between two or more countries. One of the most important of these areas is the Liptako-Gourma region, also known as the Sahel tri-border area. Fighters of various affiliation that engage in combat, often receive reinforcements that come from a neighbouring country. Reinforcements are able to cover important distances in a relatively short time onboard motorcycles or pickups.Terrorist groups' characteristics vary. Sometimes, motorcycles are escorted and supported by pickups. Some other times, groups converge to an established rally point, and, only then, when they have reached a certain number of members, launch their attack. Reading these characteristics can help security forces understand the probable affiliation of the group and, most importantly, their intentions. Terrorists seem to be procuring their motorbikes by stealing them from the local population or by looting premises of government administration or military bases, and also, by smuggling them mainly from Nigeria and Togo.#sahel#mobility#insurgent#terrorism#counterterrorism#insurgency#mali#burkinafaso#nigeria#niger#chad#westafrica#nationalsecurity#borders","Google Analytics Cert Click on my profile, ""more"" and ""connect""Google Analytics Cert Click on my profile, ""more"" and ""connect""",,,,"['sahel', 'mobility', 'insurgent', 'terrorism', 'counterterrorism', 'insurgency', 'mali', 'burkinafaso', 'nigeria', 'niger', 'chad', 'westafrica', 'nationalsecurity', 'borders']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Communications Africa/AfriqueCommunications Africa/Afrique,"African organisations face higher susceptibility to phishing attacks, with a 36.7% Phish-prone Percentage (PPP) compared to the global average of 34.3%.KnowBe4's 2024 report highlights the need for robust security awareness training to mitigate cyber risks in Africa.""Cybersecurity challenges in Africa require a combination of regulation, guidelines and security awareness training. Particular focus is needed on threats like deepfakes used for political manipulation, especially ahead of major elections in various African countries. More public-private partnerships are essential to build capacity, address the skills shortage, and improve resilience in the digital world. Investing in Africaâ€™s youth and providing cybersecurity training opportunities can fill the skills gap and also address youth unemployment,"" remarked Anna Collard, senior vice-president of content strategy & evangelist Africa at KnowBe4.Read more:https://zurl.co/bzSi#Cybersecurity#Africa#PhishingAwareness",388Â abonnÃ©s388Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['Cybersecurity', 'Africa', 'PhishingAwareness']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Bangaly KabaBangaly Kaba,"The importance of Information and Communication Technologies (ICTs) as the internet in the global information society cannot be exaggerated. Africa needs access to robust information and communication tools to acquire the resources and efficiency essential for sustainable development. That is why the President Houphouet Boigny stated three decades ago:â€œAfrica missed the industrial revolution, and it cannot afford to stand aside and let the communication revolution go by, too.â€Unfortunately, internet use is still lagging despite the widespread diffusion of mobile technologies throughout the continent. Instead of addressing the issue, a government somewhere in the region deliberately restricted internet and related media access, preventing its inhabitants from participating and benefiting from our information society. People use unsafe means to access a few media, potentially exposing them to the most critical cyber risks.Can anyone explain to me what could be a good idea for such an endeavor? My studies and many others clearly showed the positive impacts of internet-based communications technology on knowledge creation and dissemination, the rise of digital entrepreneurship, free speech, oversight of political wrongdoing, etc. The list is endless. Of course, I do not deny a few unintended consequences inherent to all human creations, but they largely underweight the limitless advantages of emerging digital communication technologies, especially in African countries. This arbitrary restriction is not happening in Cote dâ€™Ivoire, and again, thank you, President Ouattara, for not compromising the competitiveness of his beautiful country, even though his government is a victim of the most severe attacks on social media.Â French will follow:PrÃ©sident Ouattara et le cas de Cote dâ€™Ivoire, est un cas dâ€™Ã©cole. Il y a des prÃ©alables Ã  la fourniture et a lâ€™Ã©closion des nouvelles technologies de lâ€™information et de la communication et parmi celles-ci, figure lâ€™Ã©nergie dont lâ€™Ã©lectricitÃ©. Sous le leadership dâ€™ADO, le pays a atteint une couverture oscillant entre 80 et 90% de dÃ©serte en Ã©lectricitÃ©, un taux Ã©galÃ© par aucun autre pays en Afrique Sub-Saharienne mÃªme pas le Nigeria. Je comprends difficilement les critiques acerbes surtout Ã  lâ€™interne Ã  lâ€™endroit de ce bÃ¢tisseur hors pair contemporain. Ceci rappelle bien la formule utilisÃ©e une fois par le premier ministre dâ€™alors du QuÃ©bec, Daniel Johnson, dans les annÃ©es 60, et qui se plaisait Ã  dire Â«Quand je me regarde, je me dÃ©sole;" quand je me compare
content: je me consoleÂ».""

Communications Africa/AfriqueCommunications Africa/Afrique,"How are cyber threats evolving in Africa for 2024?Kaspersky's recent insights shed light: cybercrime continues its surge across the continent. In South Africa alone, IoT attacks skyrocketed by 28% in Q3 2023. Meanwhile, phishing attacks surged by 134%, a worrisome trend seen in other regions too. Notably, Africa witnesses significant attacks on industrial control systems (ICS), impacting crucial sectors like energy and manufacturing.What's the advice? Kaspersky's principal cybersecurity researcher,David Emmemphasises proactive measures: anticipate state-sponsored cyber-attacks and an AI-driven surge in spear-phishing. To counter these, businesses must adopt robust technologies like threat feeds, advanced security systems, and incident response solutions. It's time to fortify defenses against evolving cyber threats!Read more:https://zurl.co/rfOn#KasperskyInsights#CyberThreatsAfrica#CyberSecurity",388Â abonnÃ©s388Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['KasperskyInsights', 'CyberThreatsAfrica', 'CyberSecurity']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Antoine RenauxAntoine Renaux,"ğŸŒ Understanding Societal Warfare ğŸŒSocietal warfare is a low-intensity, non-kinetic war in peacetime that relies on non-military means and aims to exploit internal contradictions within the targeted model. It seeks to undermine the fundamentals of a state or society.There are three main arenas:- The State- The Economy- The Societal sphereThe fundamental mechanisms include:- Altering individual perceptions of reality- Delegitimizing authority- Exacerbating radicalizationIt is an exceptionally complex and subjective form of conflict, often indistinguishable from domestic socio-political contestation, and tends to escalate with technological advancements.#SocietalWarfare#LowIntensityConflict#Security#PSYOPS#PoliticalWarfare","Analyste Intelligence Ã©conomique & gÃ©opolitique; DÃ©fense

GTI Software & Networking AfriqueGTI Software & Networking Afrique,"The MIT report on#CyberResiliency investigates how the frequency and sophistication of#ransomwareattacks has been increasing almost exponentially in recent years, with over 80% of organizations having been targeted within the last 12 months alone. author: Communications Africa/AfriqueCommunications Africa/Afrique,"African organisations face higher susceptibility to phishing attacks, with a 36.7% Phish-prone Percentage (PPP) compared to the global average of 34.3%.KnowBe4's 2024 report highlights the need for robust security awareness training to mitigate cyber risks in Africa.""Cybersecurity challenges in Africa require a combination of regulation, guidelines and security awareness training. Particular focus is needed on threats like deepfakes used for political manipulation, especially ahead of major elections in various African countries. More public-private partnerships are essential to build capacity, address the skills shortage, and improve resilience in the digital world. Investing in Africaâ€™s youth and providing cybersecurity training opportunities can fill the skills gap and also address youth unemployment,"" remarked Anna Collard, senior vice-president of content strategy & evangelist Africa at KnowBe4.Read more:https://zurl.co/bzSi#Cybersecurity#Africa#PhishingAwareness",388Â abonnÃ©s388Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['Cybersecurity', 'Africa', 'PhishingAwareness']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Communications Africa/AfriqueCommunications Africa/Afrique,"How are cyber threats evolving in Africa for 2024?Kaspersky's recent insights shed light: cybercrime continues its surge across the continent. In South Africa alone, IoT attacks skyrocketed by 28% in Q3 2023. Meanwhile, phishing attacks surged by 134%, a worrisome trend seen in other regions too. Notably, Africa witnesses significant attacks on industrial control systems (ICS), impacting crucial sectors like energy and manufacturing.What's the advice? Kaspersky's principal cybersecurity researcher,David Emmemphasises proactive measures: anticipate state-sponsored cyber-attacks and an AI-driven surge in spear-phishing. To counter these, businesses must adopt robust technologies like threat feeds, advanced security systems, and incident response solutions. It's time to fortify defenses against evolving cyber threats!Read more:https://zurl.co/rfOn#KasperskyInsights#CyberThreatsAfrica#CyberSecurity",388Â abonnÃ©s388Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['KasperskyInsights', 'CyberThreatsAfrica', 'CyberSecurity']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

DroxiDat est une variante compacte de SystemBC, agissant comme un profileur de systÃ¨me pour exfiltrer des informations vers un serveur distant.Il peut rÃ©cupÃ©rer des noms d'utilisateur, des adresses IP et des noms de machine, les chiffrer, puis les transfÃ©rer au serveur C2 de l'attaquant.Contrairement aux autres variantes de SystemBC, DroxiDat ne peut pas tÃ©lÃ©charger ou exÃ©cuter des fichiers, mais il peut se connecter Ã  des ""Ã©couteurs"" distants pour Ã©changer des donnÃ©es et modifier le registre systÃ¨me. author: Carl BoyerCarl Boyer,"Selon BleepingComputer, Toyota a rÃ©cemment Ã©tÃ© confrontÃ© Ã  plusieurs incidents de sÃ©curitÃ© des donnÃ©es affectant des millions de clients Ã  travers le monde.Toujours selon BleepingComputer, Toyota Financial Services (TFS) a averti ses clients qu'une violation de donnÃ©es avait eu lieu, exposant des donnÃ©es personnelles et financiÃ¨res sensibles. Toyota a pris des mesures pour contenir la brÃ¨che, mais toutes les donnÃ©es ont finalement Ã©tÃ© divulguÃ©es sur le portail d'extorsion de Medusa sur le Dark Web.Selon BleepingComputer, c'est une exposition des informations personnelles d'environ 3,1 millions de clients de Toyota qui pourraient avoir Ã©tÃ© affectÃ©es par une fuite de donnÃ©es suite Ã  un incident de sÃ©curitÃ© impliquant plusieurs filiales de vente Toyota et Lexus. L'accÃ¨s non autorisÃ© a Ã©tÃ© dÃ©tectÃ© sur les systÃ¨mes informatiques de ces filiales, mais Toyota n'a pas encore confirmÃ© si les informations personnelles des clients ont Ã©tÃ© effectivement exfiltrÃ©es.La source de la fuite de donnÃ©es viendrait d'une clÃ© d'accÃ¨s exposÃ©e sur GitHub. Toyota Motor Corporation a signalÃ© immÃ©diatement la fuite de donnÃ©es aprÃ¨s qu'une clÃ© d'accÃ¨s ait Ã©tÃ© rendue publique sur GitHub pendant prÃ¨s de cinq ans. Cette clÃ© donnait accÃ¨s Ã  un serveur de donnÃ©es stockant des adresses e-mail de clients et des numÃ©ros de gestion. Afrique TekAfrique Tek,"What Is IT Security?IT Security refers to the set of strategies, methods, solutions, and tools employed by an organization to safeguard its digital assets - such as firewalls, intrusion detection systems, antivirus software, content filters, or any other protective measures - from theft. This may include using firewalls, intrusion detection systems, antivirus software, or content filters as barriers from outside attackers or threats entering its network - with firewalls being one such measure among many.IT security should conform to laws, regulations, and guidelines to protect business data. These laws and regulations ensure companies can count on reliable information protection regarding availability, confidentiality, integrity, and authenticity.#afriquetek#securitysystem",131Â abonnÃ©s131Â abonnÃ©s,,,,"['afriquetek', 'securitysystem']";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;
